element_texts.text: Completed

Chicago June 13th 1888
H.B Stone Esq. 

  Genl Mang W.B.&Q.R.R. 
    City

Dear Sir. 

  Following is the report of Opr. F.S. who with 4 men are stationed at Aurora Ills. doing guard duty, etc. 
  Opr reports that at 1 oclock A.M. and remained on duty guarding the R.R. Co. property until 6? oclock p.m. - found every thing safe - at 5 p.m. Opr was called to the office of Mr Rhodes - who told opr to detail one of the men to shadow one of the new engineers name Wagner. Mr Rhodes informed Opr that the Engineer (Wagner) made frequent visits to Chicago. and that he (Mr Rhodes) suspiconed Eng was in sympathy with Strikers. Thereupon Opr detailed B.F. Ray to shadow Engineer. Both Ray and. Eng left on Train No 14 at 5:30 P.M. for Chicago- Opr Instructed Shadow to keep track of the Engineer until he returned to Aurora and then at 6 p.m. I was relieved by unlcear Culkin?and men whom Opr detailed as follows: Officer Goodrich to watch all trains Coming and going and to escort all Passenger Trains going West. Officer Garrison to Patrol from the Depot to Main St. and watch all trains Coming and Going and to look after all switches on his beat. - Officer Culkin to watch
Completed

the Depot and Yard and to Escort all Trains going East. Opr then went to supper and returned to duty at 7:30 and at 11 p.m. Officer Ray returned from Chicago and reported that he went on Train No 14 to Chicago where the Eng left the Train and went to the Hotel Brislot on the D.W. unlcear of Canal and Adams its and left his overcoat. He then went west on Adams to Jefferson Sts North on Jefferson St to Madison St. East on Madison St. to the Grand Central Hotel on the N.W. Corner of Canal and Madison Sts. and remained about 15 minutes in the Barbershop. He then went West on Madison St. to Jefferson St. where he boarded a Blue Island Ave unclear and got off on the Corner of Blue Island Ave and Taylor St, He stopped in a Kentucky Liquor Store and had a Drink. He then went to 388 W. Taylor St. and remained there about 15 minutes - He came out accompanied by a Lady then went west on Taylor to unclear Ave then North on unclear Ave to Madison St. and East on Madison St. to Halsted He left the Lady who boarded a Blue Island Ave bus. He then went East on Madison St. to Canal and then South to the Brislot Hotel - got his overcoat and went to the Union Depot and Took Train no 17 leaving at 9:45 P.M. and arrived at Aurora at 10:55 P.M. Opr then detailed Officer Ray to watch all trains and Escort all passenger Trains East - Opr left Sergt in charge at Midnight, who remained on duty with them until 1 a.m. and found everything safe. Nothing of Importance occurred other then has been reported
Wednesday June 6th 1888
Opr further reports that he relieved unclear and his men
Completed

as usual at 1 a.m. and found everything safe. and remained on duty until 6 p.m. Opr was called to that Office of Mr Rhodes at 8 o'clock a.m. and was instructed to be at the Mayor's Office at 10 a.m. to be sworn in as Deputy Sheriff - Opr reported at the Mayors Office as instructed with all his men at 10 a.m. and all were sworn in as Deputies - Opr returned to the Depot and remained on duty until 6 p.m. when he was relieved by Sergt Culkin and men - and detailed them to their usual places of duty and they remained so until Opr again relieved them at 1 o'clock a.m. the next morning - nothing more to report.
Thursday June 7 1888
Opr further reports that men are detailed as usual that everything was quiet and nothing of importance to report. The he relieved and was relieved by Sergt at the usual hours.
Friday June 8. 1888
Ops further reports that he relieved Sergt and was relieved bu Sergt at the usual hours and that men were all detailed as usual - But at 1115 p.m. Opr reports that Officer Goodrich saw a man on the front platform of the mail car behind the Engine - Officer ordered him off and asked him where he came from - he said he came from Chicago. Officer told him that he could not ride on the train without a Ticket and also he could not ride on the front platform until he did have a ticket. The man said he wouldn not buy a ticket and
Completed

that he would ride the train in spite of the Officers. As the Officer escorts all Trains going West he also Escorts this one And as the train was pulling out of town the man jumped on the front platform of the car. Officer Ordered him off but he refused to get off. The Officer put him off and placed under arrest. He was taken to the station and booked for disorderly Conduct under the name of Mike Kenney. nothing more of importance occurred during the 24 hours to report
Saturday June 9th 1888
Ops further reports that he relieved and was relieved by Sergt and that men were detailed at the usual hours and places - excepting that Officer Goodrich attended court at 9 a.m. and appeared as witness against Mike Kenny whom he arrested the night before for disorderly conduct. He was fined $13.00 and sent to jail at 6 p.m. Opr was relieved by Sergt Culkin at his men whom he detailed as above mentioned and nothing more of importance occurred to report. Your Respectfully Pinkerton's Nat Det Agcy per Mr A. Pinkerton unclear Supt West Div Chicago
Completed

Chicago June 12th 1888
H.B. Stone Esq. Genl. Mangr W.B. + . Q.R.R. 
City
Dear Sir 
Following find report of F.S. opr. stationed at Aurora Ills. in Charge of 4 men doing Guard duty on W.B.+.Q. Engrs and Firemens Strike 1888.
Opr reports 
That he arrived with two men at Aurora on Friday evening June 1st and reported to Supt Rhodes in person at Mr Rhodes' residence - and received orders from him to report again to him at his office in the morning - Opr and his men then went to the Fremont House and remained all night - and reported to Mr Rhodes at his office at 8 o clock A.M. - Mr Rhodes gave opr. instructions as to what he wanted done. saying there had been dynamite placed on the tracks, and that an Engine has been wrecked - and that he wanted opr. and his men to be on guard where they could be had upon a moment notice - as it was expected the operation would be repeated - Mr Rhodes thought it best that Opr. to remain around the Depot during the day where he could be seen by Mr Rhodes when wanted and that balance of his men should be placed
Completed

on night duty. he also placed 6 of his special police men in charge of Opr. who are also doing night duty at the different crossings - Opr suggested to Mr Rhodes to have men sworn in as Deputy Sheriffs. he said that Sheriff was adverse to swearing in Opr and his men. but that he would see him about it. And requested Opr. to report to him at 2 o clock p.m. - and that he would have the Sheriff present - at 1.15 p.m. Officers Goodrich + Ray arrived from Chicago - Opr and all his men (then numbering 4) reported to Mr Rhodes at his office at 2 p.m. as he was instructed. The Sheriff was also there and Mr Rhodes requested him to swear Opr and his men in as Deputies. Sheriff replied that he could not do so as Opr and his men were not Voters of Kane Co. Opr informed Sheriff that himself and men were all Citizens of Illinois and that the Law. allowed him to deputise us. and that he "Opr." did not see why he did not do so. - Sheriff then told Mr Rhodes to see the Mayor and have him to swear the men in as Special Police and if the Mayor refused - he "the Sheriff" would then swear the men in as Deputies. Opr remained on duty until 6:00 P.M. when he was relieved by Officers Culkin, Goodrich Garrison and Ray whom. Opr assigned to duty Viz. Officer Goodrich to watch all Trains coming and going and to escort all passenger trains. going out of town to the West. - Officer Ray at the Depot to also watch trains and to escort all trains going East out of Town. Officer Garrison to patrol from the Deport to main St. and to watch all Trains Coming and going, and also to watch the switches on his beat. - and Officer Culkin to Travel the whole yard in general. and to have
Completed

charge in absence of Opr F.S. Opr then went to supper and returned at 7. p.m. and remained on duty until 11 p.m. when Officer Culkin took charge until 7 a.m. and found everything quiet and nothing of importance to report.
Saturday June 2nd 1888.
Ops F.S. further reports That he relieved Sgt. Culkin and guard at 7 a.m. and remained on duty until 6 o'clock p.m. watching the property of the RR Co in General - when I was relieved by Sgt and his men in his command-whom Opr detailed to duty as follows. Officer Goodrich and all the men same? as Yesterday. Opr then went to supper and returned to duty at 7:30 p.m. and patrolled the Yard until 11:30 p.m. Opr left Sgt. in charge and returned to Hotel and went to bed.- Everything quiet. and nothing of Importance to report.
Sunday. June 3rd 1888.
Opr. reports precisley the same as on Yesterday. - Took charge and was relieved at same hours. and had Sgt. and men stationed same without Change. and nothing of importance to report. Yours Respectfully. Pinkerton Nat Det Agcy. By Wm A. Pinkerton Genl. Supt. Western Div. Chicago Illinois
Completed

Chicago June 9 '88
H.B. Stone Esq Gen Manager C. B. + Q. R. City
Dear Sir
Following you will please fine report of Oprs J.P and W.N?
Thursday June 7 '88
Today in Aurora activity under instruct-ions from G.W.  Rhodes, Opr remained around the city to ascertain if Bozr? returned, back up to CBQ? saw no person answering his description. Opr then went to the vicinity of J.A. Bauerarsons'? house No 75 S. Anderson St to shadow him in case he came out. On arriving there Opr saw a man answering the description of J.A.B. working around the stable. At 7:30 P.M. he went into the house. At 9 P.M. Opr saw a man pass the house and look around, this he repeated three times, unclear went west on Beutou St to La Salle then north to Fox, west to Broadway and north to entrance of Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers hall. He remained standing in the entrance about half an hour
Completed

as if waiting for some one. he unclear went unclear on Main St, East to La Salle, north to Yancy Bros Billiard Hall where a lot of the railroad unclear unclear out. Where he entered he went two unclear what looked as though they belonged to the R.R. Here for the first time Opr got a good look at this man, he answered the description of Bozr with the exception of his mustache which is black while that of Bozr is sandy. Seeing he was not the man Opr returned to the vicinity of Baueverseis? house at 10:50 p.m. saw the same man pass the house and look in as he had done before, he then went north to Fox St, west to S. Fourth?, north to Main and west the Fremont House on Main + La Salle where he engaged a room and retired for the night. Opr thought his actions very strange as this hotel is the abode of the men who took the places of the strikers. Opr here saw Opr F.W. and reported the fact to him with instructions to unclear over advise Mr Rhodes. It should be stated that when Opr discovered that this man had a black mustache and returned to shadow he saw Baueveris? and another man who had his back turned sitting in Mr. B's parlor and the rear of the house was brightly? lighted up but where he returned after shadowing the man to the hotel he
Completed

could not see any person there though the lights were still burning. At 12:15 A.M. he discontinued and retired for the night.
Thursday June 7"/88
Today in Aurora Opr W.N. left the hotel at 7 A.M. and went to Sarbests? saloon where he remained till noon. Every thing seemed quiet. Opr played a game of pool with unclear Race and in the afternoon played dominoes with Bill Unclear one of the firemen and unclear Race. There was very little talk about the "2" strike unclear Race said he wishes they would declare the strike off so he could get another job, unclear he would try and get back to the "2" again but in case he fails he will try the Central RR. He said he did not belong to the brotherhood but sympathized with them and stuck. Opr remained in the saloon till 9 unclear where they closed up. Bowles did not put in an appearance. At 10 pm Opr discontinued. Everything was quiet up to that time. Your Respectfully, Pinkerton Nat Det Agcy Wm A. Pinkerton Gen Supr West Div
Completed

March 7th 1888
Mr. H.B. Stone
Genl Mangr. C.B. & Q RR City
Dear Sir
Following please find reports of Operative F.W 
F.W. reports. Aurora Ills March 5th 1888
The Opr saw two engineers take two men to the hotel, pay for their board. One of the Engineers told clerk that this made 8 men they had got off and sent home. This was report to Capt a words by letter. The Opr remains around the saloon where the men usually congregate. He got a "spot" on the two leaders of the Brotherhood here. Most of the men never go near the depot.
C.W. reports Brookfield MO March 4th
The Opr ordered Ray Stevens, Robinson Wells and Johnson to remain on duty at the Round House until 6:30 am when they would be relieved by a squad who would remained on duty until 6:30 pm - The Opr remained near the Round House until 10 pm when he placed the men charge of Opr Johnson with instructions to see that no outside people tampered with the engines to prevent anyone to talk to new men. The Opr reported to Supt Cramer? every hour
Completed

during the day for instructions. Nothing of importance occurred being very quiet. During the day several of the new men employed by the Company wanted to go uptown to make some purchases. The Opr detailed several of the men to go with them to bring them back to the Round House. Opr Stevens was not able to get any information from mixing with the strikers as they are very quiet and will not talk before a stranger. The Opr have the men who are on at night so located so that he can call them out on short notice. The Opr discontinued his operations.
Unclear reports. Brookfield MO, March 4th 1888
At 6:00 P.M. Opr went to CB&Q Round House and was on guard there until 7:00 A.M. March 5th. The Opr tried to get in with the Brotherhood Engineers but their meetings being private he being a stranger he could not get in with them. 
A.C.J Reports. Brookfield MO. March 4th 1888
During the afternoon and all night up to 7:00 A.M. Sunday Morning Opr was on watch in the Company Round House. Everything was quiet during the night.
Unclear Reports. Mendota Ills March 4th 1888
The 8 men including Opr remained on duty as previously arranged, nothing of importance being reporting during the day or night. Everything was quiet and no indication of trouble.
Completed

A.W. reports. Streator Ills March 5th 1888
At 1 pm? Opr put his men on duty at depot and Round House. The Opr had a talk with some of the strikers, they said they had won over 8 of the new men he had brought. The Opr then went to Hank Young's Billard Hall with several of the, who commenced to talk what the Brotherhood had done in Iowa in regard to having a State Examiner to examine engineers before they could unclear on any of the engines. The Opr sent one man to Paw Paw to guard a unclear engine. The Opr put 2 men on 2 switch Engines in the yards and divided the balance of the men to guard Round house and depot both day and night. The Mayor and City Marshall promised to give Opr all the assistance they could. The Opr remained around the yards until 12 oclock when he discontinued his operations. 
Opr TNV? reports Mendota Ills March 5th 1888
The Oper and 7 men remained on duty as usual, no disturbance of any kind occurring. Sanderson and 5 men stopped at this place for dinner enroute for Clinton. 
GDC reports Galesburg, Ills, Mar 5th 1888
At 8:30 Opr went to D Money's saloon on Prairie St opposite the Strikers headquarters. At 9:10 3 men came in the rear door of the saloon and had a drink. One of the party said the boys feel good over the new received from Chief Arthur. he said it is only a matter of
Completed

few days now, that the company will have to give in, the imported men at the depot are no good and the company can't afford to keep them they are a lot of hums from the East only brought here to make a bluff and as long as the boys keep away from the deport they are sure of victory. They then left by rear door. The bartender said the man who did the talking was Joe Bruso an Engineer. The Opr then went to 4 other saloons in the neighborhood but there wasn't a striker to be found in any of them. At 2 p.m. the opr went to the vicinity of the depot, on the way he met a striker who said the deport is full of bum scabs and that the company was putting [up beds for them, They then walked uptown. The opr told him he fired? on unclear but did not intend to go to work here. he said that was right, they then separated. There is a great deal of feeling against an engineer named Peterson who stuck to the company. The Opr went to D. Morley's? Saloon and remained there until 6 p.m. At 7:30 he went to vicinity of the hall and remained until 10:00 p.m. when he discontinued the operation.
J.M. reports unclear March 5th 88
The Opr went through the streets and hotels with the Engineers and Firemen. The strikers will not talk to strangers unclear unclear the head men of the brotherhood busy keeping the weaker
Completed

ones in line. The strikers have succeeded so far in getting 6 or 8 of the men who came to take their places, not to go to work they gave them $50.00 a letter and transportation home. Fireman {[Dryer?]] who was one of the strikers who returned to work. Sunday he was given switch Engine #62 to run in the yard. 3 or 4 of the strikers got on the engine and by threats and promises Dryer quit work. The Opr thinks a great many strikers would return to work if they were protected. 
P.J.K reports Chicago Mar. 6th 1888
The Opr left the agency at 10 am went to the Grand Pacific Hotel and mixed with the striking Engineers and Firemen, they were careful not to discuss their opinions on the outcome of the strike. There was a closed meeting held in rooms 34 and 36 on 2nd or 3rd floor between Chiefs Arthur and unclear and committee of unclear and C.M. SPP? It was a secret meeting and Opr was unable to get its contents. The Opr heard an Engineer ask some brother Engineers what was the condition of the Strike, apparently he was an engineer from some of the other Brotherhoods as he said I was told to get what information I could and find how the boys are getting on and respond to the Brotherhood. They told him he had better see Chief Arthur. The Opr tried to find out who this man was that made the inquiry but no one seemed to know him
Completed

6.
The Opr discontinued his operation at 1000 P.M.
W.L. reports Chicago March 6th, 88
The Opr went to C.M. ad S and P RR yards at 8 am. Everything was very quiet, no talking going on with the RR men. The Opr than went to C.M? depot, here the men seemed to stand up for the Brotherhood Engineers. They said the CB and Q Officers must give in to their demand, from there will be a general strike on all the western roads there was no disturbance there so the Opr then went to Grand Pacific Hotel. Here the office was filled with Engineers firemen belonging to the Brotherhood. Mr Bush one of the Committee arrived today from Downers Grove. he said "the boys will fight it out this time". Mr Arthur's rooms are filled with a good many new comers. The Engineers and Firemen are very careful what they have to say to strangers. There will be new men here tonight from Galesburg, also some delegates from New York to see what they can do to help the brotherhood. At 9 P.M. Opr discontinued the operation. Yours Respectfully Pinkerton Nat Det Agency By Wm A. Pinkerton Genl Supt West Div
Completed

Chicago, Aug 22 1888
H. B. Stone Esq

    Genl. Mg. C. B. & Q? R. R.
           City

Dear Sir:

     Following you will please find report of Opr.? H. H. F.

Friday, Aug. 17th 1888
Today in Aurora Opr.? took a walk around town at 8.30 A.M. to see if could find some of the men.  He found Frisby at Young's cigar store and Bauriesen? in his buggy in front of 106 Broad way  Frisby, Byron & Quilain came up from Young's and all four of them went into the store #106 Broad way, where they stood talking until 9.15 A.M. when Bauriesen? came out and drove away,  Frisby and the others going to the corner of Fox St. where they stood until 10.30 when Frisby went home.  Froom that time until 3 p.m. he did not see anyone but heard some men at the U. S. Express office speak of the strike and denounce the management of the road and said it was the worst they ever saw, and said if Mr. Stone had given the men what they asked for, the road would
Completed

at least be four or five million dollars ahead, instead of paying inexperienced men and detectives, and one of them said it was well & good to talk about a thing that they did not exactly know, & said if any of them were in business, he thought they would want to manage it themselves and not let their help do it, he said the company was fighting for a priciple which all sensible men must know, and what it had paid for detectiions was by no means thrown away for if the men had succeeded in destroying the offices at Chicago, which they would have done only for the detections, the company would have been a great deal more money out to say nothing of the lives that would have been lost, and one of them asked him if he believed those dynamite stores and he said that he did and that the company of the Pinkertons would do nothing of that kind, as they had too good a standing for that, they then left in their buggy which was standing in front of the office and drove over to the west side.  At 3 pm. Opr. found Westling, Bylander, Maloney, and a crowd of about 15 men in the saloon at #8 River St. and he was about to leave when Westling saw him and called for Opr. to come to him, and
Completed

opr. told him the distance was just the same and if he (Westling) wanted to see him (Opr.) he would have to come to him (opr.) so Westling did and asked Opr. to go fishing with him in the morning.  Opr. told him he did not want to be fooled another time and Westling promised to be.on time and asked Opr. to play a few games of pool or dominoes, with him and Maloney, and Opr. told him he would but he was not going to drink with or treat those strangers, Opr. told them they must take him for banker to spend money as feely as they did when they got it for nothing, and they said they did not get it for nothing and Opr. asked them what they were doing, and Maloney said they were fighting for their rights and to down the "scabs" and they company, and Opr. asked him what they were dong to down them, and Westling said to never mind that something would turn up before long, and if the rest were scared he was not.  They played several games of dominoes and Opr. could get nothing from them.  He left at 5 P.M. and took a walk over to the east side and passed Baureisen's house, going back and fourth on the street he saw Baureisen in his buggy driving out of town at 6. 30 P.M. towards
Completed

Montgomery, Opr. started to follow him but was unable to keep up with him, so he went to the cemetery and waited there until 8 PM. for him to return but did not come back that way, opr. then went to his (B) house but saw no one and could not see his buggy so he went back again and waited until 10 P.M. when he went home.  Yours Respectfully Pinkertons Nat'l. Det. Agcy by W. A. Pinkerton Gen'l Supt. West Div
Completed

Chicago, August 21st 88

H.B. Stone Esq
Gen'l Mgr, C.B. + Q. R.R.
City
Dear Sir   

         Following you will please find  reports of Op N.N.F for Aug 18th & 19th.

Saturday, Aug 18th,88
Today in Aurora Opr got up at 4am and went to Wistlings house 388 S Lake St and started from there with Wistling at 5am to go fishing.  They took a boat and went down the river to Montgomery, but they had poor luck and only caught 6 fish.  Opr commenced talking about the strikes and Wistling told him he did not know what day but it was not very distant, they would declare a boycott on the whole L system, the circular mentioned in previous reports have not yet reached Aurora.  Wistling said the Brotherhood would certainly win the strike if they would only stick together but some fools did weaken  (([unknown])) and they would keep a good lookout for them and expel them at once Opr
Completed

asked him if they had given up the idea of  compelling the company to come to terms by destroying the larger bridges, and he said there had been some talk about it, but ever since the Dynamite case the "bosses" kept all those things to  themselves and talk but very little about it except to intimate friends and old  hands, he said he did not think they would do it before they considered the strike costs as they were sure the company would not take the old men back, he said for his part he did not care how long the strike would last as long as he got his $50 per month he said he had nothing to do and he could live  on that.  Opr asked how long the Brotherhood would pay him, and he said until he got a job or went back on the road.  It was near 8am and they had not had a bite for a long time, Wistling got tired and wanted to go home Ofr had a 1/2 pint bottle of whisky with him  out of which he traded Wistling several times and gave him the last of it, and asked him to try a little longer, but could get nothing more from him, so at 8.30am, they started for home, Opr left Wistling at his house and promised to meet at #8 River St in the evening.  Opr started out a-
Completed

again at 3.45pm and saw (([unknown])) Frisby & Byron on the corner of Fox Street & Broadway, and he went into 113 Fox St and bought a cigar and sat down and watched them, when they walked a little way North on Broadway and stopped in front of the store #8, Opr went into the drug store #27 and bought a glass of soda water and a cigar and stood there watching them, but they remained there so long that Opr had to leave the drug store and he went to the corner of Fox St, when he met Mortimer and stood talking to him, at 5.45 (([unknown and unknown])) started up Fox St. toward their houses and soon after Frisby started also.  After supper Opr. went over to #8 River St where he found Maloney, Bylander and shortly after Wistling arrived.   They took seats around a table and played dominoes and talked about different things and finally got to talking about the strikes, but Opr. could learn nothing new.  A lot of outsiders came in about 7pm and Opr. left.  Opr. saw Frisby and Reed on Broadway and they went to the  Hall at 9.15pm.  He saw Frisby  & L (([unknown])) come out and go toward the York St bridge and go in the saloon #5 River St.  Opr. went into Smiths cigar store and got a
Completed

cigar and talked to Mr Smith in and at 10pm.  Frisby and Ludlaw came out and went to York St. Bridge when they met two girls and a man, they talked for some time and 10.45 PM Frisby left and started for home which he reached at 11PM.  Opr then discontinued.
Sunday, Aug 19th, 1888,
Today in Aurora Opr, started out at 8.45 AM to look for some of the men.  He saw Frisby at 9.50AM going to church with a woman.  Opr. took a walk over on the west side and met Westling & Maloney on York St bridge and they asked him if he did not want to join them and get a tram and go to the (({camp??])) meeting at (([unknown])) they should start at 2PM & Burns & Johnson would go along with them and take their wives along as they had their own horses, and Wistling said he could get a tram for four dollars and they could find a fourth partner and make it one dollar each.  Maloney and  Opr. went to a blacksmith named Nelson and he said he was willing to go and it was decided to meet at 7 Burns' house #181 (([Jallena St.])) at 1.30PM Opr. went to the the meeting place and found them all there and they started at 2.10PM.  In starting Wistling was to drive with Mrs Brown in their
Completed

buggy and Mrs Brown was to come in the buggy with Opr.  It being very hot they drove slowly and about 15 minutes after they started Johnson asked Opr. if he would come and drive his horse for a while, Opr. went and drove all the way to (([unknown])) which they reached about 5PM.  They remained at the meeting until 6PM and then took a walk around the place and at 7PM they started for home.  Opr. and Wistling got in Johnson's buggy and the ladies and their husbands got in the larger buggy.  Opr. & Wistling got  to talking of the strike and Wistling said they would make up their minds as to the boycott this week.  They reached Aurora at 9.30am & Opr. left them and  discontinued.
Yours Respectfully 
Pinkerton Nat'l  Det agency
by W A Pinkerton
Completed

Chicago Aug 18th 1888
H.B. Stone Esq
Gen'l Mgr. C.B. & Q. R.R. City
Dear Sir:
Following you will please find reports of Opr F.W. for Aug 15th & 16th
Wednesday, Aug 15th 1888
To-day in Aurora the strikers had a meeting in the morning which was pretty well attended and from a good many of the men went to Sieberts? saloon. Beauviser? went to Miller's shoe store and then went home. Bob Nickson did not go fishing as the man who was going with him, backed out and Nickson was at Young's cigar store a good deal of the day and evening. John unclear said that he was so lazy and tired that some times he felt that he should go to work, if it was only to saw wood. Opr went around to the different saloons and through the streets but did not see any of the men drunk or disorderly. Mears said he intended to go to La Crosse where Jack Sparron? is, but he has not
Completed

2.
received a reply to a letter he wrote to Jack. Opr watched the R.R. track from South Aurora to New York unclear until after 1 A.M. but did not see any of the strikers around.
Thursday, Aug 16th 1888
Today in Aurora Opr went out with Tom Hornly who was under the influence of liquor, & he said he wanted to see Van Race, who he (T.H.) had heard had got some citizens on the west side to go to Mr Rhodes in his (V.R's) behalf for work. J.H. called him a - - - - and said he (V.R) had been trying to run the west side unclear since the time they took the vote in the Hall. Van Race has been trying to persuade the strikers on the west side to go back on the road. When Tom and Opr walked along River St. they saw Van Race coming toward them and just before meeting them he went into a store and T.H. said, "Did you see the ---- trying not see us, now stop and see him come out" they did, and Van Race came out but walked in another direction, & T.H. & Opr went into Seibert's? Saloon and from there to unclear O'Neil's Saloon in the N.W. Hotel and O'Neil said to T.H. what old man Smith bad been down to see him (T.H.) and had left word as to where he could meet him and
Completed

3.
it was about a unclear T.H. said he was not in the dynamite business just then, and Opr asked what Smith what was, and if he was the father of E. Smith the Dynamiter, and O'Neil said he did not care to hear that subject discussed in his place. Hornly said they would not as neither of them were interested in it. From there Opr & T.H. went back to Seibert's Saloon and asked for Van Race and the bartender said he had gone to Chicago, than he had went yesterday and had not got back yet. There was something wrong as Opr & T.H. had seen him come out of Seibert's at 7:15 A.M. from Seibert's they went to Fred Chapin's saloon where T.H. lay down on a table to take a sleep. Opr went to Young's and told Stanley and McGran who went for T.H. to take him home. The strikers has a meeting in the afternoon and evening.  Bauriser? was at Seibert's, but Opr does not know whether he saw Van Race or not, and when he left there he had a yellow paper bag in his hands, he walked over the N. York St Bridge and up M. York St, passed the R.R. tracks, through the square and toward home this was about 7:30 P.M. Opr was at Farwell's Saloon, Hick's Saloon
Completed

4.

and Young's Cigar Store during the evening. Opr received a letter from Mr. Rhodes telling him to let the Agency know of Mr. Emmerson's? whereabouts, he being at Topeaka Kansas. also of an engineer by the name of Hadlock going to work on the Joliet new road. Opr remained in the vicinity of the Q tracks until after 2 A.M. but strikers were around after 11 P.M. 

Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton Nat. Det. Agency
by W.A. Pinkerton
Gen'l Supt West Div

Dear Sir,
Following find report of Opr T.S. Officer in charge of Guards at Aurora dated July 31st 1888
Officer reports that he went on duty at 7 a.m. and remained on duty up to 10 p.m. and found all safe and his men reported all safe during the night, - and at 4 p.m. he placed his men on duty as usual. at 4 p.m. and visited them unclear up to 10 p.m. where he went to bed.
August 1st 1888
Officer further reports that he went on duty at 7 a.m. and relieved his men who reported all OK for the previous night and Officer remained on duty all day and until 11 p.m. At 7 p.m. Officer posted his men as usual and visited them several time before discontinuing for the day. found everything quiet and nothing of importance to report and at 11 p.m. discontinued.
August 2nd 1888
Officer reported that he went on duty as usual at 7 a.m. and relieved his men who reported all safe during the previous night and Officer remained on duty all until 9 p.m. at
Completed

night and has nothing of importance to report except that at 3 p, he received orders to discontinue guarding duty at Aurora and return to Chicago with his men. accordingly at 9 pm Officer and his men took Train no 50 for Chicago. Arrived here at 11 p.m. and report to the agency.
Your Respectfully

Chicago Ills. Aug 15. 1888.
H.B. Stone Esq.
Gen'l Mang C.B. & Q R.R.
City
Dear Sir
Following find report of Opr F.W. dated at Aurora. August 10th 1888. (Friday)
Opr reports that while in Heains saloon this morning he met Nickson a Striking Engineer and Frank unclear a new Engineer and all talked about fishing. went to New York St Bridge and fished for 3 hours. Then they parted Nickson said to Opr. "That fellow is a scab but he seems like a nice fellow." Bauviseau? is in St Louis expect him home Saturday night. Mears expects to go to La Crosse where Jack Spanner is. 
The Strikers Ball Team expect to go to Joliet to play Ball.
Opr heard unclear George tell De Gerald Saurtry? and Watkins that a Brotherhood man of other roads would go to see the General Manager Mr. Stone. Watkins is taking unclear of some horses for different people near where Watkins lives on Fox Dr. 
While in Siebert's Saloon there was a discussion about St Louis unclear it was claimed that it was the end of the strike, that whichever way that unclear would go would decided the whole of the strike. 
But if the Strike would be kept up unclear
Completed

2
Arthur would resign his position.
There are very few strikers around in the Evening a very few at Youngs. The Strikers had a meeting: Tom Hornly asked Mears what was done at the meeting Mears said that there was a letter read from some Lodge from Chicago which came to try and get the exact no of men out of work now.
Opr was around the Depot and R.R. Tracks till a late hour.
Saturday August 11th 1888.
Opr further reports that while in Young Bros Cigar Store he overheard a conversation about a letter which had been recieved by the Lodge here coming from St. Louis and a striking Engineer said that Bauevisu? wrote it and Santhey? said no it must be from Lodge.
Santhey? and Dutchy Koegle were together a great deal today: Koegle was drinking Whiskey in unclear and wanted to make a bet of Twenty Dollars on a foot race. Later while in Young's Cigar Store, Opr talked with Young, Mears, Freeman, De Gerald Nickson and others and Opr was asking if the R.R. Co was doing any where near the business it did before the strike and Young said not any where near half. why, the Brother hood know pretty near every thing that goes on and this train that leaves here for the East is not Carrying enough passengers to pay the crews that run the trains. And all these scab Engineers have to go to a school at the Different divisions where they are taught like school children what to do. Young said "just wait till after the St Louis Convention is over. and something will happen that will surprise every body. Op said why
Completed

the boycott". and Young said no not that! This then started the talk of Boycott and Freeman said why if we would get the Knights of Labor to Boycott the L road that Road would have to shut up all business alltogether.
Opr was with others of the Strikers at Seibert's Saloon Farwells Shorts unclear in the Evening also at Hains Saloon at the Depot.
Dorn? a Striking Engineer lost $5.00 at the Ball Game last Friday and he said did not care but perhaps it would be a long time before he would get any more money.
Tonight as unclear the specials have been relieved Opr has watched around the R.R. tracks Depot till a late hour but did not see anything wrong. 
Sunday August 17th 1888
Today while among strikers opr reports that he learned the following
Bauversiu is back from St Louis. the he had called a meeting for Monday morning That the Boycott would not be brought about at once. Mike Unclear is here on a Visit. he is unclear on a branch of the Illinois Central.
There were very few strikers in either Youngs or Schicklers Cigar Stores. about 15 of the Strikers went down the river to a fish fry!
Talking to Hank? Young Opr asked him how the strikers go so much information about the railroad he said that they all have lots of Friends on the R.R. who post them. that they can find out any thing right from the head Office. Opr said it would make the R.R. people mad if they knew of it. Young said he guessed it would.
Tom Barry and unclear were around all day and night
Completed

4
until after 1 a.m. in the morning. Opr shadowed them a while about midnight he went to Heaires? to Heeks to Empire House and also up to the Hall as far as the Park on the way home, Barney and unclear remained at Graniffs, the 1st night that Bowles and his brother stayed here
Oprs saw Fisher and Koegle on the streets during the day and evening. At night Opr watched near the Depot until after 2:30 A.M. walked the tracks as far as the bridge, The Police say it is very quiet now. very few strikers on the streets more new men. If it would be of any benefit to the R.R. Co. Opr could rope some of the new men but Opr has not done so thus far.
Monday August 13th 1888
Operative further reports That in the morning he saw Bauervisu? Langworth Shea and Mike unclear talking at the corner of Main and Broadway they had a long conversation B - then went to Millers Shoe Store where he wrote a letter and from there went to the Hall where a large meeting was held, while the meeting was in progress there was a large hurrah, which Opr afterwards learned that Bauervisu? was speaking and Explaining what was done at the meeting in St Louis, That it had been voted there to carry on the Strike, to raise the Strikers wages and to tell any strike which is in need of money that the Brotherhood will assist them. Opr saw unclear and Frisbrie have a long ernest? talk together at the corner of Fox and La Salle Sts. Opr overheard Frisbie say G- D- his heart if he does that he will be clubbed till he can't walk. Taylor Mears Freeman and myself had just come out of Farwells Saloon - and
Completed

5.
crossed the street, when Bauervisu? called unclear to him and said " where are you going" Opr could not hear more
Van Race was a Siebert's Saloon and wants to sell his house
Dean is anxious about a note coming due on his house at 428 N.Y. St.
Langworth John Gretcourt Watkins Dean and Hank Young had a long talk in Youngs Cigar Store in which Nickson name was mentioned and also Bauervsen?
In the evening they had a Meeting after which Barry Koegel Snover Panthay and others and Opr had a man named McNulty. There are three McNultys one an engineer and 2 who are firemen. This on Opr and those above mentioned had was the Engineer Opr thinks! They had all just been in Heeks? when Ton Barry came along and called them all out Barry said something to Koegle who there call unclear McNutly and Mears one side and Joegle accused McNulty of making application for work on the scab road. McNulty said it was a dirty lie and Koegle said "now look here where did you do. did you not ride over the scab road. and the answer was. no. only from here to Streator.
Koegle then said "have you a time table of the 2 at your house" The answer was "The only one I have is the old one before the strike
"Did you not vote to have the strike off, Answer"
"No not by a g- d-.
Koegle said You lie
The reply was "you ask Bob Nickson"
Koegle said Nickson is as bad as you are, go talking to scabs. Now tell us are you going to work
Completed

or did you make application for work
The answer was "No"
Did you see Forsyth or Mr Rhodes. No
Then Koegle and his man walked over to the Depot Platform and Santhy said "wait till I go over and smash him" Snover would not let Santhy go and Koegle parted with this man McNulty who is a small man well built dark hair and mustache Dressed in Black.
Tom Barry and Koegle went off together somewhere
Santhy said "You just bet the 1st of them fellows that brakes ranks will get it:
Today was pay day by the R.R. and Watch factory there was no drunkeness of disturbance of any kind. The police said it was a very quiet pay day.
Mom's Reddy and 2 more Tramps have returned one a man from Naperville who has done time for Freight Stealing. The other was from Streator
Opr was around the Depot and R.R. Tracks till after 2 a.m. and watched the new men also but saw none of them drunk.
Your Respectfully
Pinkerton's Nat Det Agcy
Per W.A. Pinkerton Gen'l Supt West Div
Completed

Chicago August 15th 1888.
H.B. Stone Esq.
Gen'l Mang C.B. & Q R.R.
Chicago
Dear Sir
Following find report of H.H.F? dated at Aurora Ills August 9th 1888.
Operative further reports that 8 a.m. he started out and found Frisby at corner of Fox St. and Broadway talking to Quinlan? and White Opr left them there and went to Post Office when Opr came back they were still there Opr went to 113 took a cigar and seated outside the store Opr watched them till 9:30 they then parted and Frisby went home. At 1 p.m. Opr went to No 8 River St. found Westing and Bylander they had several glasses of beer together there and started at 2 p.m. for the Ball Game. The conversation was about the strike but nothing new. Opr tryed to find out about the circular but failed and was afraid to go ask too much about it for fear he says of being suspected. They return from the Ball Game at 5 p.m. and went cor. of Fox and B-way to Farrars Saloon and had a glass of beer. made an appointment to meet at 7:30 p.m. at No 8 River St. Opr again saw Fribie outside the Hall among a lot of the strikers. Opr left them and went to No 8 River St. found Westing Bylander and 6 other men drinking beer. Opr joined
Completed

2.
then Opr asked Westting to come and see the minstrels at the Opera House to get him away from the crowd. He and Bylander came. They all went to the Opera House. Opr tried to get him to Introduce Opr to different parties, he spoke to bu he did not understand Opr. Opr was unable to get any information about the stirke, it was all about the ball game or the show, when we left there Opr lost sight of Frisby and could not find him again. 
Emmerson is still out of town and Bauerviseu? and Goding Opr has not seen.
Saturday August 11th 1888
Opr further reports that at 10 a.m. he got sight of Frisbie cor of Fox & B-way talking with Byron Quinlan and White he soon left the party and went home. Opr went over to West side to look for Westting and Bylander at No 8 River St they were not there. Opr stayed around the street all day but failed to see any one before 4 p.m. where he found him at the Imperial Hotel. Ope left him and went to No 8 River St. found Westting Bylander and 3 of their friends there, and they all played pool and drank several glasses of beer but all they talked about was the picnic tomorrow. At 5:15 6 more of their friends entered. Opr found he could gain nothing by remaining longer so left them and at 8 p.m. again went there stopped a few moments and made up a fishing party for Sunday or Monday. Then going along Broadway Opr saw Frisbie and Quinlan going to No 5 River St. Opr went into the Cigar Store at No 8 River Street and watched. They stayed at No 5 until 9:15 came out and went to York St. Bridge, they stayed there talking
Completed

to 2 women and then went wast and north on Oat St. Opr left them and went home. on his way home Opr stopped a while at Downer pl. and River St. and saw the same parties return and go into the Rink on the Island. There was a dance going on at the time. Opr did not go in but waiting outside till 11:15 when Frisbie came out by himself and went home.
Sunday August 12th 1888
Opr further reports that at 10:00 A.M. he went to Mr Burns house to find out about the picnic got the information, Westting Bylander and 17 other Scandinavians were to "partake" or participate in the festivities. Opr was asked and consented to go with them. At 3 p.m. they left Aurora in two Wagons each one excepting Opr had his girl along. They were provided with Sweedish punch, beer and Cigars, which was charged up to all. They went to N Aurora to man by name of Olsons' house. left the wagons there and went to a lawn, some of the party played the Violin and they all danced, after a short time Opr and Westting commenced talking about the strike, talked about their cause for the strike, that the company was paying poorer wages than other Companies and that when a man began to earn fair wages he was discharged without any real cause. And that the reason why was that the Classification was the only way for the company to hire cheao labor. That they were sure to win in due time that the men now on the road were not able men spoiled the road and burned and otherwise disabled their Engines. Opr asked him whether or not some of the Locomotives were spoiled by the strikers
Completed

4.
although the new men got the blame for it yes! he believed there were a great many done that way Opr asked again about the Circular, but did not get an answer as some of the other men came up to them and they had to quit talking, later some of them got Drunk and started a row. Burns' his wife and Opr left at 9 in Burns Buggy which his son had bought out there. after arriving at Aurora Opr looked for Frisbie but could not find him
Tuesday August 14th 1888
Opr further reports: that he started at 4:15 a.m. to meet Westting to go fishing to Montgommery, Opr waited till 5:15 for Westting did not come. Opr then started for his house 388 S. Lake St. found him, and was told that he could not go fishing as his wife wanted him to do some garden work, they put the fishing off until another day. Opr went back to Hotel and at 9:30 took a walk and found Frisbie at Youngs Cigar Store. Opr left him there and went to 115 Fox St. took a Cigar and chair and seated himself on the side walk waiting to see Bauereisen?but he did not come, Frisbie Quinlan and Byron came to the corner of Fox St. & B-way and stayed there talking until 11 a.m. when Frisbie went home. In the Afternoon at 4, Opr went to 8 River St to look for Westting as he promised to be there. Opr waited there to 5 p,m. when Westting Bylander and Maloney came down with 2 other men and all played pool and again drank several glasses of Beer. Opr tried several time to lead the conversation to the strike but only once Opr got it started and found that the Circular to the business men to get them to take their Freight on some other
Completed

5
other than the "L?" as the "L?" has started from the West and not yet come to Aurora. Opr left them at 6 p.m. at 7 p.m. Opr was again at No 113 Fox St talking to Tasmer? and Mortimer, and found that the unclear begin to loose their farith in the strength of the Brotherhood at least Opr heard Mortimer say he believed the men lost faith in the strike and had lost the strike and that he was not the only one who thought so.  At 7:15 Frisby came and went to the dance at the Rink Opr remained around until 10:15 when he saw Frisbie come out and go home. Thereupon Opr discontinued for the night.
Yours Truly
Pinkerton's Nat Det Agcy
per W.A. Pinkerton Gen'l Supt
West Div

Chicago, Aug 14th/88
H.B. Stone Esq
Gen'l. Mgr. C.B. & Q. R.R.
City
Dear Sir. -
Following you will please find report of Opr. H.H.F.
Monday, Aug 13/88
Today in Aurora at the usual early hour Opr. started out and took a walk around through the streets but failed to see any one. At 11 A.M. he again went out and saw Baureisen? at the store 110 Fox St. and Opr. went in-to #113 and got a cigar and then sat out side on the side walk, and after a while Frisby came up and joined Baureisesen? and they went to the post office and from there they went home. At 3 P.M. Opr. went to the saloon #8 River St. and found Westling, Bylander, Maloney (switchman) and four other men, Opr. intended to leave the place but was asked to join their company, they played pool, and domin-os and had several drinks, Opr. got Westling + Bylander separated from the others and they told Opr. that the
Completed

2
firemen's + switchmens monthly pay had been raised $10,00 and said that showed that they had money. Westling and Opr. are going fishing to-morrow morning at 11.30 A.M. and Opr. thinks he can get all he (Westling) knows out of him, Maloney said he would down every "scab" he could get a hold of + that the Company had to come to terms inside of thirty days, or fail and put every thing in the hands of receivers. Opr. left the place at 10.30 P.M. and went home.
Yours Respectfully

Chicago, Aug 11th 1888
H.B. Stone Esq
Gen'l Mgr. C.B. & Q. R.R.
City
Dear Sir,
Following you will please find report of Opr. H.H.F.
Friday, Aug 10th 1888
Today in Aurora opr. reports that he was unable to find any one at all in the forenoon. In the afternoon he saw Frisby at 3 P.M. at the corner of Fox St. and Broadway Opr. went into #113 and got a cigar and stood outside watching him, when a brake-man, Opr. thinks his name is Franlin went in and got a cigar, and shortly after the marshall and two men whom Opr. did not know entered, and the Marshall asked Franlin how the new engineers got along, + Franlin answered splendid + said that they had a good lot of men now, and the Marshall told him not to take part for the "scabs" + Franlin replied that the "scabs" were every bit as good as the Brotherhood men if not better, + then left, and one of the gentlemen who was with the Marshall said he had the opinion that
Completed

2
the brakemen and the strikers were on one side, and the Marshall said that they were but there were always some fools who thought the Company was doing right, and said he did not care what he (Franlin) said, and what ever the company did, it would go to h- anyhow if they did not take their old men back, they then left, and Frisby was still at the same corner with Duilan? + Byron, but shortly after went home. Opr. went over to the west side of the saloon #8 River St. to look for Westling + Blander, but did not find them. At 7 P.M. Opr. again saw Frisby at the same corner, and e started for the hall, and Opr. went to #8 River St. + found Westling + Bylander in company with 15 other men. Opr bought a glass of beer and started to leave, when Westling noticed him and asked him to come to their table, so Opr. went and Westling asked him to go fishing in the morning, + Opr. told him he would go some day next week and again started to leave the saloon, but was stopped and asked to have some beer. Opr. saw no way of getting out so he remained and the conversation was about the old country. They had several glasses of beer and remained in the saloon
Completed

3
until 10.30 A.M. when they left and Opr. got Westling separated from the rest and asked him whether the business men were willing to obey the orders of the Brotherhood and he said that the circular was not yet sent out but he said he believed rather than be boycotted they would obey. He said they were sure to win, that they got stronger every day and the Company got poorer, that it had the poorest management that was ever known and it could not stand 30 days longer before it would be anxious to get them all back. He said they were bound to win, if not by fair means, they would not be afraid to take any step that would bring them victory. By this time they had reached Fox St. bridge, and Westling asked Opr. where he lived and Opr. told him, + he said he lived on Lana? St. and was going home then. Opr. left him and took a trip around to see if he could find any of the boys but failed and went home. 
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton's Nat. Det. Agency
By W. A. Pinkerton
Gen'l Supt. W. Div

(who lost $5.00 on Base Ball) Koegle Conklin, Mean Freeman Byron Miller and he went to the Base Ball Ground with Young DeGerald Byron, Mike Quinlan.  DeGeald did not hav any money so Young paid his way for him while at the game.  Quinlan said to an acquaintance that he was not looking for work as he expected to go back to work on the 2.  when Quinlan said this DeGerald and Young laughed. Hicky is now Washing at unclear Stable? at 12 oclock midnight Pautley? had a fight with one of the Base Ball players, but it did not amount to anything  Respectfully Submitted  Pinkertons Nat Det Agcy.  unclear A. Pinkerton.  Genl Supt. West. Div.

At 6.30 P.M. opr. met  Frisby going to the hall, and opr. left him there and went to look for Westling and found him at the saloon # 8 River St. with a crowd, so opr. took a beer  and left and went to 27 Broadway, a drug store and bought a cigar and remained there watching the hall. Chicago. Aug. 9th 1888.  H.B. Stone Esq. Mgr. CB&Q.R.R.  Dear Sir.  Following find report of OptH.H.F. dated at Aurora. August 7th 1888.  Opt reports that at 9 a m he found Frisbie at Schmicklers Cigar Store on Fox St.  Opt went in and took a Cigar and listening to the Conversation between Frisbie Miller and Quinlan and Opt could hear, the words ("it would be a good thing if we only Could do it, we ought to have some of them Pinkerton S of Bs mixed up in it here.)  Frisby said he was sure there were a good many in Aurora (meaning Pinkerton Men) but to get to them was the Trouble.  They then left and seperated at the Cor of Broadway  Afternoon at 3 p.m. Opt went to Burns saloon to see if Westling would be around.  found him but could gain nothing new.  Opt left him after obtaining the enclosed Circular from him which he claimed to have lost.  Then at 640 p.m. Opt saw Frisbie again with the same men as he went up to Mr Rhodes House with.  The man Opt thought was one of our Opts and was sitting on the Stone fence on the Cor of Fox and Lasalle Sts, Opt went to 113 and met Ray a Painter had to treat him to a Cigar, watched the party to 7.15 when Frisbie went to the Hall and the other two Opt found at Youngs playing pool.  Opt watched there until 830 p.m. when he had to meet
Completed

Opt. W. on the Bridge  After leaving Opt W. Opt found Frisbie again at the Imperial Hotel in Company  with the same, men, they left there and went to 113 Fox St from there to 109  Opt went into 113 and got a Cigar and asked Tasmer to have a drink.  took him to 109. but all Opt Could hear was talk about the Ball Game.  From there Frisbie went home.  and the Other two left him at the Gate and Started to the Fox St Bridge and met some women and went to Lincoln Park and from there Opt did not see them any more and at 1050 Opt left for home.  Yours Respectfully.  Pinkertons Nat Det Agcy.  per Wm A. Pinkerton  Genl Supt Western Div.
Completed

Chicago. Aug 8th 1888  H.B. Stone Esq  Gen'l Mgr. C.B.&Q.R.R.  City  Dear Sir:  Following you will please find reports of Opr. H.W.F. for Aug 5th & 6th  Sunday, Aug 5th 1888  Today in Aurora at 9 A.M. opr. started out and took a walk around but Baureisen was the only man he saw and he was in his yard when Opr. passed at 10a.m.  He saw Frisby at Young's cigar store at 11.30 A.M. and at 12 noon met Baureisen on Fox St.  In the afternoon opr. saw Frisby standing on the cor. of Fox St. & Broadway at 5.30 P.M. talking to the Bartender from 5 River St and three other men Opr. watched from #113 Fox St. and while sitting there Baurisen came up and went in and got a cigar, but nothing was said.  They went to the corner & stopped there for a few minutes after which they all started towards the Hall, they stopped on corner of Broadway and Main St. and some went up to the Hall but returned at once. At 7 P.M. Baureisen
Completed

2   started home and at 7.15 P.M. Frisby and the bartender and two other men started for the saloon #5 River St. and stopped outside and looked around and then went into the saloon.  Opr. went to Smiths cigar store and took a cigar and watched them until 8.30 P.M. when they came out, and started towards the York St. Bridge where they fooled with a girl until 9.15 P.M. when they went to the Park and staid there until 10 P.M. when Frisby started for home and opr remained in the vicinity until 11 P.M.  Emerson is not in town and opr. did not see Yoding during the day.  Monday Aug 6th 1888  Today in Aurora opr went about town as usual but did not see any of the men until 2.15 P.M. when he saw Frisby at the Corner of Fox St. and Broadway.  Opr. met Chas. Westling at the same time and he asked opr. to go and see the ball game and as Opr. thought he might learn something went with him to the corner of Fox & River Sts where they met Fasmer & Mortimer and they asked opr and Westling where they were going and Opr. told them to the ball game and they said they were going to the same
Completed

3    place so they joined them and went into the saloon in the basement at the cor. of Fox St. & Broadway where each of them treated & from there went to Tasmers Cigar Store where opr. treated the cigars and then started for Hurds Island to the ball ground, there Opr. fixed it so Westling and Opr. got a seat seperated from the rest and got to talking about the strike.  He told Opr. again about the circular and said that everyone that does not obey the circular will be boycotted, and that the Brotherhood is getting stronger every day and will surely win this strike.  He said it may be that they will have to fight some time but they would do anything to win their rights and that the dynimate plot is nothing to what will come if the Company does not give in.  He said he knew only a little of what the head men do, but he did know that they would not give in.  Opr.asked him if they got their pay and said they got their forty dollars the third of the month, and that was all opr. could get out of him.  All four of them left the ball game and went into Shorts saloon where they treated, and while they were there Quinlan and Byron entered but all the
Completed

4   talk was about the ball game.  At 7 P.M. opr. again saw Frisby outside of the Hall, but as opr. made a turn around the block he lost him so he went to #113 Fox St. where he got a cigar and took a seat outside to watch and see if any one should come around.  He remained until the store was closed at 9.45 P.M. when he left and walked arounf until 10.45 but did not see any body.  Yours Respectfully  Pinkerton's Natl Det. Agcy  By W. A. Chicago Ills.  Aug 8. 1888.  H.B. Stone Esq.  General Manager CB&QR.R.  Chicago  Dear Sir  Following find report of Opt F.W. dated at Aurora. Friday Aug 3rd 1888.  Opt. Reports that.  Today he spent among the strikers and in watching new men also whom several he shadowed to saloons but they only drank an occassional Glass of Beer and not enough to intoxicate  Frank Don a new Engineer wants me to take a trip over the road here with him.  I introduced Don to DeGerald and Pearson 2 strikers  DeGerald shook hands with Don but Pearson would not.  Don treated  Tom Horly a striking Engineer was drunk  he showed Opt. $20.00  Youngs Cegar Store was pretty well filled up there were 3 meetings in the Hall. today morning afternoon and Evening.  but few strikers on the streets today and tonight.  Opt watched at Farewell saloon.   Mears Farwell and Raymond.  they were treating each other  Raymond said he had to go to work someplace he could not stand this.  A Striker by name of Weldon said in Heecks Saloon that he would go back if the rest would.  that he was tired of doing nothing
Completed

2   Shea and Conklin was talking together near the Brotherhood hall.  Opt heard them say Rhodes and Forsyth will be there  In the Evening Opt watched the Tracks both above and below the depot.  There are a great many Tramps and other people riding everyday on the front end of the Mail and Express.  Cars going west from here at night  Opt remained up and around the Revy Cos property until 2.a.m.  Saturday Aug 4th 1888.  Opt reports everything very quiet here and was among a good many of the Strikers and went to the Ball Game with them but there was no information to be got.  Everything seems to be very quiet  Opt says he watches new as well as old men.  and has an Invitation to take a trip on the Road with a man, a new Engineer, and will do so upon instructions  Sunday Aug 5th 1888.  Today Everything was very quiet among the strikers here.  There were 2 German picnics and 2 fish frys.  along the river.  Opt went to one of them with several of the Boys.  and returned early.  There were but few people in Youngs Cigar Store and at 8 oclock p.m. Hank Young said he might as well close up as to burn Gas.  Opt saw Koegle Sting? Farwell and Taitro? having quite a Conversation together  Tom Horly was around the Empire House where he boards continually.  he said look at the scabs getting fat while we are getting poor.  In the Evening Opt watched around the RR
Completed

3   and Tracks from the Depot to South Aurora.  Opt walked to South Aurora and back again and did not see any of the Strikers up to midnight.  Hicky and Stanfield claim that the strikers friends have lost faith in them and have no interest for them.  Opt says the principal thing the strikers are doing is hunting work.  Monday Aug 6th 1888.  Opt Reports further  Reddy Snorr? went to work at Berlins Livery Barn  It was stated in Youngs Segar Store that there are 35 Engineers from among the Strikers who are now on the Minn and N.W.R.R.  Raymond said in Sieberts Saloon that the 1st of next week the Boycott would be placed on the C.B.&Q.  Op asked him how it was to be worked.  he said there would be notice sent to all the Business men and Manufacturers and the Business men would have to Boycott the Road or loose a lot of Trade.  Frisbie was down Town early in the morning was at Youngs most of the time.  he had a long talk with John Guttcourt and then went to Millers Shoe Store 110 Main St. from there to the Hall.  Afterwards Opt saw him in Heecks Saloon with Koegle.  Koegle was around most all day at the Brotherhood Hall.  Sting? Farnsworth and 2 others were in a fight in Chapmans Saloon.  but was stopped before anything serious occurred.  Tom Horly was drunk again and got into a fight with Joe Hoppy  Opt got Tom Horly away to one side and away from the saloon.  where they met Mickey McGraw who took Tom Home.  After 12 oclock the only
Completed

men Operative saw on the street were Mears. Smith (Elk Brother) Koegle. Raymond. Tom Barry Snorr. Taitro? and Freeman and McGraw.  Optr emained until late watching around the street and Depot until after 2.a.m.  Yours Respectfully.  P.N.D.A.  per W.A. Pinkerton.  Genl Supt.  West Div.

H.B. Stone Esq.
General Manager. C.B&Q. R.R.
Chicago
Dear Sir
Following find report of Opr. H.H.F. dated at Aurora Ills. August 4th 1888.
Opr reports that he started out at 9 a.m. but did not see any of the strikers and then Opr went to West side to Burns Saloon No 8 River St. in Basement. While there Opr reports, a man came in who was a striking unclear Charles Westling and unclear Scandinavians Opr and Westling soon became acquainted they had some beer and played a game of pool, after which they talked together to become acquainted and finally talked about the Q Strike. Opr says that Westling is firm (in his opinion) that "the Boys" will win the Strike and that the 1st move will be to Boycott the Merchants that ship on or unclear Freight via CB&Q. A printed circular to that effect is going to be sent out and over the C.B.&Q R.R. The Labor organizations are going to help the Brotherhood in the Boycott. Opr did not want to pump the man too much at once so dropped the subject and Opr says if you want him to pump the man he thinks he can get out all the man knows on the strength of same Nationality. Opr left the saloon with promises to go again and went about town and at 11:45 he met Bauereisen?, his wife and children in a
Completed

2.
Buggy coming down Fox Street. They went to the P.O. from there a grocery store and then home. In the afternoon at 5:15 Opr saw Frisby for the 1st time during the dayt he was on the Corner of Fox and Broadway talking to Byron, White, and a G.A.R. man was showing a map of Andersonville Prison and selling Books. Opr watched them. They stood there until 4.30 p.m. Frisby went to Youngs and from there home. At 7 p.m. Opr saw Bauereisen Frisby Byron White and a lot more enter the hall. They left there at 9.10 Bauereisen went home Frisby went to Youngs and from there he and Byron went to No 5. River St. Opr then went to Smiths Cigar Store and waiting until 10.05 when Frisby came out along and went home.
Yours Truly,

Chicago Aug 7 1888
H.B. Stone Esq
General Manager C.B. & Q R.R.
Chicago
Dear Sir
Following find report of Opr F.W. dated at Aurora Ills. Saturday Aug 4 1888.
Opr reports that he pt in his time most of the day shadowing both strikers and new men.
There were some of the new men who went into a Clothing Store on Broadway known as the Bankrupt Store and after the new men left Opr talked with the proprietor who said he could get more money out of the new men than the old men and that he only wished he had what the strikers owed around town. Opr asked him if they owed much and he answered about $18.000. That Pete DeGerald after the strike went to proprietor Bankrupt Store and wanted a Coat and Vest and said he would pay for it soon as he was paid by the Brotherhood and he has not paid for it yet. The amount was $22.00.
Tom Hornby was pretty drunk today he said he could get work when ever he wanted it. That there was 25 men of the Strikers from Aurora now on the Santa Fe. 18 on the Illinois Central and about 35 all told on other roads. Hornby said he
Completed

2.
was not intimating that the strike was over But that he wanted to be at work. Hornby got pretty drunk before night. John J. Cunningham a striker has been appointed a Letter Carrier. Bauereisen & Alshuler his lawyer were around this afternoon. Bauereisen passed Youngs today and Freeman Mais and Shear were sitting there. Freeman said Ive wondered how Uncle John was meaning Bauereisen and Mais said he would not like to be in his place. There were very few in Youngs today.
In the Evening Koegle and Sarto and several other strikers were around {{Heecks?]] Saloon cutting up a police office who guards La Salle St. From Main to NY Strs seen there and said he had some names to report to Marshall Walker for misbehavior on the Street      about 8.30 p.m. Opr approached East End of New York St. Bridge and saw two strikers sitting there as if watching for someone. Opr left the Bridge and they sat down and looked to see if they were shadowed then they went to Siebert's Saloon. Opr went into Siebert's Saloon later but they were not there. Others entered and went down stairs  Opr talked to Garrity who has Van Reece place tending Bar and he said there were v games of dominoes going on downstairs. Then as Opr H.H.F. was going to remain on the West Side Opr F.W. returned to the East Side and watched around the R.R. Depot till after 2 p.m.
Yours Respcty
Pinkertons Nat Det Agcy
per Wm A. Pinkerton Gen'l Supr West Div

Chicago Aug 7 1888
H.B. Stone Esq
Gen'l Manager C.B. & Q R.R.
Chicago
Dear Sir,
Following find report of Opr H.H.F. dated Aurora August 3rd 1888.
Opr reports that at 8 oclock a.m. when he went to mail his report his Landlady asked him to see what was the matter with her clock. Opr took the clock to his room and unscrewed the works and put them in his pocket and watched his change to get out unseen and went to watchmaker Goodale on River St and had him repair it at once. It was full of dirt and the Balance Spring was broken Opr accidentally broke spring unfastening the works. Opr got the Clock at 2.50 p.m. and no one knew he had left his room. At 4 p.m. Opr started out to locate men but Frisby was the only one Opr saw. He was at Corner of Fox and Broadway talking to White and Farmer. Opr went to the P.O. for his mail and got a letter from Mr. Rhodes to meet him at 5.17 p.m. at South Aurora Depot. Mr. Rhodes told Opr that Bauereisen and Gooding were still at Galesbring and gave Ope instructions to keep Frisby located when Opr returned to Fox St he found Frisby and the same man outside 113. Opr went in and had a Cigar tried to listen but their conversation could not be dis
Completed

tinguish. To avoid suspicion Opr left the place with a sweedish Saloon keeper from the, west side. At 7 p.m. Opr again found Frisby outside the hall he left the hall at 8.45 and stopped at the Corner of Fox St talking to White and 3 other men. Opr went into 113 and found Mr. Mortimer a Patern Maker Opr treated to cigars took chairs and sat down outside the door - the whole party came in and had Cigars and talked about the Ball Game. Frisby went hom 9.30 p.m. Opr watched until 11 p.m. but nobody left that place. Mr. Rhodes told Opr that it was not necessary to watch his house. Emmerson is not in town. 
Yours Respcty
Pinkertons Nat Detective Agcy
per W.A.Pinkerton
Genl Supr West Div

Chicago July 27th 1888  H.B. Stone Esq Gen'l Mgr. C.B.&Q.R.R.  City  Dear Sir:  Following you will please find report of Opt. F.W.  Wednesday July 25th 1888  Today in Aurora Opr. reports that he attended the trial in the Court Room at the Post Office, but before going in he was talking to Frisbie and Raymond, two strikers, and Frisbie said that if Bowles got clear he would get the worst whipping he ever had and Raymond said that someone would get him alright, but if any one would be punished it ought to be Bowles.  Opr. watched Frisbie all through the morning session of the court, and in the afternoon sat near to him, and when the striker's Attorney, Mr. Alschuler made an objection which was sustained by the Court, the strikers and their sympathizers clapped their hands and stamped their feet and Frisbie did the same, and a little later a
Completed

2   drunken switchman who is called Bow hollowed, "hang him" meaning Bowles who was on the stand at the time, and Frisbie laughed but said nothing.  The Marshall Walker was talking to Dutchey Koegle and Godding and Dutchey asked him what kind of grub he kept, and the Marshall replied that he would cook something fresh for him.  It is rumored about that Koegle's father and mother have arrived from Chicago.  Opr. looked all over for Emmerson both in the forenoon and afternoon but could not find him, and he also failed to see Van Race.  Tom Kyle was in the Court Room.  The strikers had a meeting in the evening but Opr. could not learn what was done.  The strikers now claim that Bob. Hickey is a detective for the Company, but he says the first one he hears say so he will break his d-- head for him, for the leaders of the Brotherhood knew better and Opr. asked him how they knew and he replied that they knew he would not turn against them, but said he would like to get work of any kind now.  Young Brothers' cigar store was so poorly patronized to-day that Opr. heard a man say that he did not believe they took in $1.50 today.  In
Completed

3   the evening Opr. saw Tom Hornly who told Opr. that about 10 P.M. a man came to him at the Tremont House and called him to one side and asked him if his name was Tom Hornly, and Hornly replied that it was, and the stranger said he had been sent to see him and that he had been told that Hornly was the right man and the stranger said he was a professional gunsmith and he could fix any kind of a gun or machine and between them (Hornly and the stranger) they could fix them all.  Hornly said he did not know at first what the man was doing, but he caught onto it and said he thought right away that this man was a fly copper, but was dressed like a tramp so he followed him and saw him talk to a city Policeman and then go towards the Fox St. bridge but Hornly says he did not follow him any further.  Opr. and the rest all laughed at him and told him it was all a lie, but he said he could prove every word he said by the people who were around the Empire House at the time.  Opr. watched for the tramp until 1 A.M. but could not see him.  He went as far as south Aurora and all over the west side
Completed

4   and asked in an off handed way if a tramp had been run in by the police but there had been none.  At 1145 P.M. Tom Barry who also attended the trial very reguler came up and asked Opr. to lend him his umberella saying he had some important buisness at attend to, and it was raining very hard.  Opr. let him have it and he walked toward the Brotherhood Hall.   #110 Main St the shoe store where the letter was to be returned to, which was brought out in the Bowles testimony, is kept by Freeman and Miller.  Mr. Freeman is quite an elderly man and lives at 73 N. Fourth St.  Mr. Miller is Freemans Son-in-law and lives at the same place.  It is in this store where Beaurisen does a good deal of his writing.  Mr. Rhodes told Opr. that Geo Godding received two telegrams on the 23rd of last March one in the morning at 10 am which read thus,  To Geo Godding  Mismark.  tell Dumphy O.K.  J.A. Beaurisen  The one in the afternoon at 3 P.M. read as follows.  To Geo. Godding  Call meeting to-night.  have Dumphy met me at the 5.15 P.M. sure
Completed

5   all O.K.  Bismark  J.A.B.   Opr. mentioned the above to show that Geo Godding and J.A.B. understand each other in having a cipher to use in their telegrams and this could be found out by asking them when they are on the stand.  Yours Respectfully  Pinkerstons Nat. Det. Agency  By Q.W. Pinkerton  Gen'rl. Supt. W. Div.  A.R.

Passenger Depot - That several strikers made their appearance around the Depot during the day which is unusual but they did nothing out of the way. and kept to themselves. Officer reports that

everything passed quietly during the day and at about 6 o'clock officer heard that Employees of the Joliet & Elgin Road were going to "do up" Employees of the ? road. Therefore Officer went to S. Aurora and remained on duty there none of the parties made their appearance and nothing occurred - Officer's men reported all quiet during the night

July 20th 1888
Officer reports that at 2:30pm Mr. Rhodes called him to his office and requested officer to find one August Koegel one of the striking engineers saying that the Sheriff had a warrant for his arrest Officer told Mr Rhodes to inform Sheriff to keep watch of and close to officer and he would find Koegle for him. Officer did not find or see Koegle until 8:30pm. when he found him at the Fair, and Officer shadowed him until he went to his room at Hecks? Hotel at 12 clock. Officer then left Officer Ray to watch him. and reported to Mr Rhodes who told Officer that Koegel was going to Chicago on the 6am. train. Officer then went to Sheriff ? house and told him of the fact. that Koegel was in his room and
Completed

3
that Sheriff could get him. Sheriff said he would come down at 5am. Officer then returned to Hotel and watched up to 5am. where the sheriff came and together they entered the Hotel and placed Koegel under arrest and the Sheriff took him in charge.
Officers men report all safe during the night and nothing of importance to report.
July 21st 1888 and July 22nd 1888
Officer reports that himself and men went on and off duty at the usual times and places and nothing of importance to report everything quiet and safe.
July 23d, 1888
Same as yesterday excepting that Officer was requested by Mr Reese the train master to go over to S Aurora at 1am as Barnums Circus was expected to arrive and for Officer to watch there. he did so and reports nothing of importance to have occurred.
July 24th 1888
Officer reports that himself and men went on and off duty at the usual time and place and they report all quiet and safe. during day and night on their respective beats. 
July 25th 1888
Officer reports that himself and men went on and off duty as usual. and everything quiet and safe excepting it had been reported to officer that stones had been thrown at the North End of the yard. Officer in charge sent Officer Goodrich there with instructions to arrest anyone throwing stones or in any interfering with the men while one duty or molesting
Completed

4
the Company property. Officer Goodrich remained there up until 2:30am and reported everything quiet during his time on duty. nothing further of importance occurred worthy of mention during the day or night.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkertons Natl Det Agcy
per Wm A. Pinkerton
Genl Supt. West Div

H B Stone Esq
General Manager ? R.R.
Chicago
Dear Sir.
Following please find report of G.W. dated at Aurora Ills. July 24th 1888.
Today in Aurora while among the strikers, Opr learned the following
That a striking Engineer by the name of Shea intended to leave town said he had promise of work on the Wabash Road.
The Strikers claim to have made about $500.00 on their Fair. Tom Bonny claimed $800.00
Dutchey Koegle and Tom Bonny were together a great deal and while in ? saloon Bob Hickey asked Koegle if he (?) had seen Reese and Koegle said, not yet.
At Youngs there were not many strikers during the day or evening.
Opr did not see Emerson but looked for him but failed to see him.
The strikers held a meeting in the afternoon from 2 til 4 and in the evening from 8 til 9:30 
Opr saw Bauersen several times in the morning he went to the shoe store No 110 Main St. stayed about an hour then went to the Hall.
Completed

2
Opr saw him in the afternoon going to the Hall and afterwards saw Goding with him going toward their home
Fisher was at Youngs Cigar Store several times Once he said he would like to get at something he was so tired of doing nothing that he had got so strong he could like any ? on the road.
At night Opr managed to see Opr H.H.Y. and give him a letter Opr. had rec'd from Supt McGinn for him.
About 10:30pm there was one of the Clanceys (a brother to the ?) and the youngest Young bro Tom Huber and 3 other Young men from the Watch Factory standing just opposite the Tremont House. and on the Porch was Officer Snyder and several new men there these men stood on opposite side of Street and called them all the names they could think of. S--- of B---- and Pinkerton Bastards. Scabs and other names until a Police came in sight and they moved on.
Opr remained there around near the Depot and RR track till after 1:30am.
Respectfully Submitted

per Wm A. Pinkerton
