Chicago July 26th 1888.  H.B. Stone Esq.  General Manager C.B.&Q.R.R.  Chicago  Dear Sir.  Following find report of opt. H.H. Forbes. dated at Aurora Ills. July 23d 1888.  Opr. reports that at 5 p.m. went to the P.O. recd a letter from Opt. W. giving a discription of Bauereisen Goding and Frisby and notice that Emerson must have left Town on Saturday  Opt then started to see if he could find any of the aforementioned men.  went to their usual stopping places but did not see them or any of them until 7. p.m. when Opt saw Bauereisen at the Hall entrance.  he is a man about 35 years old 6 ft. high dark complexion broad shoulders and weights 200 lbs..  dressed in a dark suit.  black stiff hat  he entered the Hall at 7.05  Opt started round the block to see if any of the rest were around  did not see any one but at 810 opt met Mr & Mrs Finch Miss Code and Mr Warren Green and Cagen.  all roomers at Mrs Finchs  they were going to the Fair.  they took Opt by surprise coming up at his back. and urged him to go to the Fair with them.  after some time Opt consented to go to avoid suspicion. and at 9.45 Opt had a chance to go to the vicinity of the Hall but found it closed.  then Opt returned to the Fair at 1030 saw his party again and treated the party.  and while in the Ice Cream parlor. Opt thinks he saw Frisby with
Completed

2   a lady.  "he answered the discription fully of Frisby" Opt at 12 o'clock saw Bauereisen but in such a Crowd that it was impossible to keep track of anyone any length of time.  Opt at 2 a.m. went home with his party. and returned again to the Fair and stayed until 4. a.m. but was unable to learn anything new or see his men.  therefore at 410 Opt returned to bed.  Yours Truly.  Pinkertons Nat Det Agcy  per Wm. A. Pinkerton Genl Supt  West Division
Completed

Chicago July 26 1888  H. B. Stone Esq  Gen'l. Mgr. C.B.&Q.R.R.  City  Dear Sir:  Following you will please find report of Opr. H.H.F.  Wednesday July 25th 1888  Today in Aurora at 8.20 A.M. Opr. started out and mailed his report of yesterday and took a walk around Broadway, York St. La Salle St. and Fox St. in hopes of seeing some of the men but failed to see any of them, so he went home and  waited for Mr. Green and Cane, as they promised to meet him there, and go to the trial together, but they did not come so Opr. went to the court house alone, and found Green and Cane there ahead of him.  Opr. then had dinner at 1 P.M. while standing at Fox St. bridge, Baureisen passed him on his way to the court and a few minutes later Goding also passed him.  Opr. saw Frisby when he entered the court house at 1.15 P.M. but failed to see Emerson.  Opr. stopped at the Hall until 4 P.M. when he left and
Completed

went to the corner of Broadway and Fox St. and stood there until it began to rain, when he went home.  At 5 P.M. he again started for the Court House but when he got there he found every body had gone.  He walked around Broadway, York St. La Salle St. and at the corner of Fox St. saw Baureisen and Goding going up the hill.  When Opr. passed the hall at 6.45 P.M. he saw Frisby sitting on the steps so Opr. loitered around and at 740 P.M. Goding came up to where Frisby was and at 750 P.M. Baureisen also came up.  They staid there until 9.15 P.M. when Baureisen and Goding started south on Broadway.  Opr. followed them to the corner of Fox st where they stopped for a few minutes and then started east on Fox St. on their way home Baureisen going to 75 S. Anderson St. and Goding to 428 Fox St. after Opr. left Goding he returned to where he left Frisby but when he got there he found that Frisby had gone and as Opr. could not find him up to 1030 P.M. he went home.  Yours Respectfully  Pinkerton's Nat'l. Det. Agency  By W.A. Pinkerton  Gen'l. Supt. W. Div  AR?
Completed

Chicago July 24th 1888.  H.B. Stone Esq  General Manager C.B.&Q.R.R.  Chicago  Dear Sir.  Following find report of Opr. F.W. dated at Aurora Ills. July 23rd 1888.  Opr reports that while among the strikers he learned the following  Dutchy Koegte said that he was on to 2 Pinkertons and one of them had asked him to take lunch with him.  said he would not eat with a Pinkerton S of a B for the Q. Road.  Koegte and West Fisher had a long talk together walked away from the rest of the men.  unclear  Wm DeGerald are hard workers at the Fair.  they are there Constantly since the Fair Opened  Farnsworth is going to work in the Country Johnson a Striking Switchman said youl see there will be a harder time for the Company than the Dynamite.  At The Youngs there was not much talk about anything only about the Boycott and what the Brotherhood will do and etc.  Nothing Official coming from the Brotherhood direct.  But mearly talk of the Strikers that have the least to do with it, Freeman said Well all the Wholesale places and Manufacturers of
Completed

2   Chicago will live up to the Boycotte.  such talk is indulged in a great deal  Tom Horly returned to Aurora today and has been under the influence of Liquor.  Op. went to the fair in the evening there was a large Crowd there so that it was impossible for Opr to get on to the Dancing Floor.  dancing was kept up all night it being the last night of the Fair.  Everything was quiet here.  Opr saw Goding Fisher and Koegel talking together  Opr has not seen Emerson for 3 days  Opr heard 1 man say at the Fair that Emerson had gone home to Sandwich and that he would soon be back.  After Opr left the Fair he watched around the Depot and RR Track until after 2 a.m.  Opr reports that but few people ever go in to Youngs.  all the Strikers go to the Fair.  Respectfully Submitted  Pinkertons Nat Det Agcy.  per Wm A Pinkerton  Gen Supt Western Div

Chicago, Aug 27th 1888  H.B. Stone Esq  Gen'l Mgr. C.B.&Q.R.R.  City  Dear Sir:  Following you will please find report of Opr. F.W.  Friday, Aug 24  Today in Aurora Opr reports that he was around to different places with the strikers and learned that Charlie Dean said he would have to sell his house and go to work, that one of the Watkins can hardly read or write his name and he overhead some strikers talking about it and there came near being a fight over it, that Charle[s?] Perdien is going to see Smith tomorrow.  There were two strange Brotherhood men here from Galesburg.  Cunningham has left town and Koegle expects to spend Monday in Chicago.  Hank Young said he was glad that Van Wagner had been discharged from the road.  There were a good many of the strikers around the Depot

in the evening.  Jack Byron a brother to Tom, a striker is most always around the Depot.  Opr. remained around until all strikers had left when he discontinued.  Yours Respectfully  Pinkerton's Nat'l Det. Agcy  by W.A. Pinkerton  Genl. Supt. West Div.  R?

Chicago Illinois  August 30th 1888.  H.B. Stone Esq.  Genl Mangr C.B.&Q.R.R.  City  Dear Sir  Following find report of Opt. H.H.F. dated at Aurora Illinois, August 28th 1888.  Operative reports that Today (Aug 28th) he started out at 8. a.m. to locate his men for the day.  Found Frisby 9.30 in Corner Fox and Broadway talking to White and Quinlan.  Opt watched them home from 113 Fox St.  at 10 a.m. Bauereisen passed Opt where he was sitting outside the Cigar Store, he stopped a few moments at the Corner and went to P.O.  Frisby left the corner at 1045 am went to Youngs.  from there went to Ball Game with Westling  talked about Strike.  Westling knew nothing new.  said in a short time everything would be settled in favor of the Brotherhood  left him at 5 p.m. found Frisby at Imperial Hotel he went home at 6 pm.  opt saw him again at 9.15pm. when he came from Hall.  he went with Quinlain to No 5 River Street stayed until 10 p.m.  Opt watched them from Cigar Store No 8 River St.  from there he went to York St Bridge.  met the Girl he is keeping Company with  they started to walk North to Lake but did not walk very far before they turned back!  they
Completed

did not see Opt at all as he gave them a long shaddow.  they came back to the bridge and stood there for a while but started again towards North Ave.  the went down on the Island and stayed there until 1.a.m. when they started for home. Chicago Illinois  Sept. 17?th 1888.  H.B. Stone Esq.  Genl.Manager. C.B.&Q.R.R.  City  Dear Sir.  Following find report of Opt H.H.F. dated at Aurora Sept 14 & 15th 1888.  Operative reports That:  as usual he started out to locate his men.  and saw Bauereisen  during the forenoon he went to the Cigar Store 110 Fox St.  Stayed there till 10.15 A.M. then went home.  Opt did not see any of the rest.  at 2 p.m. according to instructions from Supt. Rhodes he met Frank W. (Opt) and they went to Sugar Grove to see McClean?.  found him and Opt F.W. started the Conversation by asking him to be Agent for lands in Kansas and Nebraska: saying he had been recomended as a good man.  but soon changed the subject - and told him that both Opts were brotherhood men, (Engineers) and asked him what it was he had reported against the brotherhood Men.  he said he had done nothing of the kind: (just then, another man who proved to be the Depot Master came up to where the 3 men were talking!) that he had never reported them as Brotherhood men: Opt asked whether he was working for the Company: he first said no but when he found out that Opts knew him, he ad-
Completed

mitted that he had run an engine in chicago but was layed off: Opt asked what he was doing now.  he said he did not know if they (Opts) had any right to ask him: but when they told him they knew he had run an Engine in Nebraska, and was now working as watchman nights for the Company: he wanted to know how Opt. knew all that: Opt said the Company was not able to make a move without Opts knowing it.  He would not say at what place he saw the 3 men or explain anything: But said, if the Company allowed: him he was willing to make a Statement to the Brotherhood about it:  The Depot Master asked Opt. Frank Wind:his name: and Opt answered Watson then asked the other Opt the same question  Opt Answered: "Henderson": he then asked what runs they (Opts) had.  Opt F.W. said he run a switch Engine from Chicago to Aurora:  McClean asked what Opts really wanted to know. of him: they said that the reports he had sent in had hurt the Brotherhood and that they wanted to find out who those men were:  After talking a little while about different things: Opt asked for a glass of water: with the intention of getting McClean away from the Station Master.  McClean started to show Opt: And Opt tried to pursuade him to join the Brotherhood and offered him the same pay as the striking Engineers were getting  he said he had been a Brotherhood man in the State of Main: but got into trouble and left: and that he was now. working: for. the Company and intended to stick to it: Opt asked him what he was getting + he said $2.50 per day:  At this time they were again joined by the Depot Master: and Opt FW.  they talked a few moments longer than drove away arriving at
Completed

Aurora at 5 p.m.  Opt left Wind at Corner of Lake and Walnut Sts: and went home.  at 6.30 p.m. Opt again started out to find his men.  found Frisby at the Corner of Fox St: Opt watched him from No 113:  Opt Met Mortimer and they had a talk with Tasmen about the turnout at Joliet the 22d of this month  Frisby started down B-way - They all went to Farrells and had beer: Opt left there with an excuse: saw Frisby at Main St.  Opt met Hoyt: a clerk in Thomworths? Hardware Store.  Opt got acquainted with him at one of the Swedish Picknics: they had drinks together: Opt asked him what side of the the Strike question his firm sided with: He said, the Companys.  and that the strike had hurt their business a great deal. -during the Conversation: he had some tickets to a ball. for the benefit of Mr. Stenson who lost his foot 2 weeks ago in the Q Shops: Opt had to buy one of him to keep on the good side of him: he paid 50￠ for ticket Opt started to leave: but Hoyt wanted to know where he was going: Opt gave an excuse.  but Hoyt said he would go with Opt: they went, crossed the bridge and returned again to No 8 River St.  saw Westling there had some beer: Opt again excused himself and went to B-way met Frisby and Dumphy coming toward the Bridge: they met some Girls and talked with them and went to 5 River St. Opt went after them and went to the Cigar Store No 8 River St. and stayed there until 9. p.m: they left and went to the Fair at the Rink: Opt followed a little later and saw Frisby Dumphy Quinlan and Gahan in the Corner having a whispered Conversation - they did not see Opt: so he went out and waited
Completed

for them  soon after all 4 came out and started to B-way and went into Farrells they did not stay long but came out with 2 other men and walked quickly up Fox St. South on LaSalle St. and went to Frisbys house 95 LaSalle St.: when it grew dark Opt went up and looked through the blinds and saw them all playing cards: at 12 m. all left besides Frisby who stayed at home.  September 15th 1888:  Operative further reports that at 9 am he mailed his report: and then strolled around to locate his men found Bauereisen on B-way outside Police Maj Murphys with several other Brotherhood men.  and at 10 am. Goding joined the party: Opt watched them from 27. B-way and when he saw Bauereisen and the others, he went up to them and stood there till 10.45.  the Bauereisen and Goding started up the hill.  and Frisby went back to the Corner.  Opt went to 113 Fox st. and kept them in sight till 1130 a.m.when Frisby went down B-way and went to Youngs Cigar Store.  from there he started for home.  Opt did not see any of them to 5 p.m. when he again saw Frisby at Farrells Saloon: which he entered with Mortimer and Tasmer they had some beer: and Frisby was playing pool with some outsiders at 530 p.m.  they left the saloon and went to Tasmers and took a seat outside the store:  at 6.15 p.m Frisby Came from the Saloon and went. home. - at 7.30 p.m. Opt and Mortimer started out to have a walk, and they met Spelman, and, Hoyt Jr. and all went to Farrells had some beer: but talked nothing but politics

Chicago Sept 18th 88
H.B. Stone Esq
Gen'l Mgr. C.B. & L. R.R.
City
Dear Sir:
Opr. F.W. reports as follows.
Aurora, Wednesday Sept. 12.
Today I spent my time among the business men of Aurora and strikers. I was told by McGraw that the brotherhood was trying to get the Republicans to come out to Aurora via the North Western, and said if they came over the "L" he would not feel like parading. he belongs to the Hiburnian Rifles. Every thing was quiet until about 11pm when a shooting affair occurred. I had just been talking to Geo. Smith (Elks Brother) and William Tatro. Tatro had just left Han's Saloon and am going home was met by a new engineer by the name of Dissell, and they had some words and Dissell drew his revolver and fired two shots at Tatro. They were both arrested. One thing I have noticed here is that Geo. Smith always has plenty
Completed

of money. he treats everybody and is mostly with the brotherhood men. The Brotherhood perhaps is using him to reach Elk in Chicago. At night I remained up as usual with the hopes of learning something but failed to learn anything so I discontinued at 2am.
Aurora, Thursday, Sept. 13th 88
Today I was sick with a cold and had chills so I kept to my room. In the evening I called on Mr. Rhodes as per his letter. He gave me further instructions which Opr. H.H.F. and myself are to carry out.
Aurora, Thursday, Sept. 14th, 88. 
As I was sick yesterday and was not feeling well today I did not go any where in the morning, but at noon as per instructions received from G.W. Rhodes. I procured a horse and buggy and met Opr. H.H. F. at Galena and Oak Sts. and drove to Sugar ? where we were to see a man by the name of McClean, who claims he overhead a plot by three men to wreck a train on the C.I. R.R. But as his story is somewhat doubtful it was thought that by H.H. F. and I representing to the brotherhood men he would give some new points or scare him off, but by being rough per-
Completed

haps not but by giving him warning in a quiet way perhaps I might on arriving at Sugar Grove we saw Mr. McClean and the Depot master out riding in a buggy. I first went to the Landlady and after asking for McClean was told that he was not in the house. I told her I thought he would sleep all day as he seldom works in the day, but only at night, she said he was generally there until dinner time and then remained around outside. She sent her little girl out to call McClean and when he came in I asked him if he was Mr. McClean and he said he was, I told him that I had been informed that I could find him around Sugar Grove and that I would like a ? to represent the Land Co. out toward Sugar Grove and other places in the western part of this County. He said that he did not care to work that way at all. I asked him what he had been doing & he said he was looking after things of interest to Railroad Co. at present. I asked him if it paid well and he said enough to satisfy him I asked him if he worked day or night and he replied 'at night' I told him that he did not need ,much sleep as the lady of the house said that
Completed

he did not sleep much during the day. He said he was a person who required but little sleep. After trying to get him to talk about his work which he would only by answering yes or no. Opr. H.H.F. and I both spoke up and I said McClean it is no use to go on this way any longer, we are two Brotherhood men and we want to know all about that big lie you told about seeing three of our men up here in a horse and buggy. He said that he did not say they were Brotherhood men and who ever said so was a liar. I told him that he had told several Railroad Officials that they were and that we knew it and he would hear from the Brotherhood again. He said "I don't see how you people found this out" and I replied that there was nothing that the Company did that we did not know and that we knew where he was supposed to work at nights and asked him if he worked in the same place on dark nights or set around the Depot and watch for detection as they got off. We told him that we wanted the truth and that it was for the benefit of the Brotherhood and we did not want anything to happen that would cause the general
Completed

public to form a bad opinion of us. He said if the Railroad Co. was willing he should make a sworn statement of everything he saw he would do it. and I asked him how he would prove all this and he said the only proof he had was what he saw. I asked him if there had been any accidents around here since he saw Jon and his friends here just then the Depot master came up and McClean told him what we wanted to know and that we were Brotherhood men and the Depot master appeared to take more interest in the matter than McClean did, and asked us where we had run and Opr. H.H.F. gave the name of Henderson and that he ran from Aurora to Chicago and I gave the name of Watson and ran of switch engineer at Hawthorne. I then asked him about the different people around there that I knew, and I saw Young Judd go by on a load of straw. I said Judd must be skiping and in this way I know both thought I was well acquainted. I told McClean that if he ever came to Aurora I would like to know it as some of the Brotherhood men would meet him. Here I called the Depot Master away so that Opr. H.H.F. would have a chance to talk to McClean alone
Completed

H.H. F. asked McClean how much he was getting and he replied $2.00 and that he would not aid the Brotherhood Opr. tried to get him to come to Aurora and join the Brotherhood and told him he would  get $5000 a month and have nothing to do but he said he would not that he had belonged to the Fireman's Brotherhood and they had left him out and that was enough for him. I asked McClean several questions but he did not seem inclined to answer, he got nervous and we caught him in several lies about his marking the buggy. he first said he could not tell the buggy if he saw it again and then he said he had it marked. I tried to make him believe that the brotherhood would be after him to take him to Geneva County Seat and unless he could prove, what he had said about the Brotherhood they would sue him for slander. He said as long as he worked for the Railroad Co. he was bound to do his duty he said he was never discharged by C.B. & L. and has always worked for them since the strike. We arrived in Aurora at supper time and I remained around the Depot. and R.R. track until a late hour.
Aurora, Saturday, Sept. 15th 88.
This morning I first saw Beauriesen coming out of the Post Office, I followed
Completed

him and he went to the Democrat Hall where he had a long talk with Dumphy. I watched them and Beauriesen took out a letter and gave it to Dumphy and he put it in his pocket. Beauriesen then went to the Brotherhood Hall. At 4.30 P.M. a striker by the name of McGuire left word at Young's that when any of the men came to send them to the Hall, but I could not learn what it was for, but the men that went there only stayed a few minutes. I went down to the Republican Head quarters in the evening and met a good many of the business people of the city. As usual I was around the R.R. track and Depot until a very late hour, but every thing was quiet, and there were very few people around.
Yours Respectfully 
Pinkerton Natl Det. Ag cy
by W. A. Pinkerton
Genl. Supt. West Div.
R.
Completed

Chicago Sept 19th 88
HB. Stone Esq
Genl. Mgr. C.B. & Q. RR
City
Dear Sir,
Ofr. H.H.F. reports as follows
Aurora, Wednesday Sept. 18th 88
I started out at 9 AM. and took a walk around through the streets but saw none of my men. In every place the talk was about the bad luck the Republicans were having as it was raining and it spoiled every thing for the night At 4 P.M. I met Mortimer on Fox St and was introduced to Mr. Mabill one of the oldest engineers in the north west. he is now working on the North Western. We stood on the street and listened to some one speaking of politics, and we went into Shorts saloon #109 three times and had drinks I drew Mabill a little to one side and in a round about way spoke of the strike, he said the Company was pretty well bled and would soon give in he said the boys would stand firm, a good many had gone away, and a good many more would soon go to
Completed

work on other roads, but the head men would stand until the "Q" gave in, he said the day was not far distant when the Company would be glad to get the old men back, that the men now working on the road were having a good time, a wreck nearly every day and he said they will gladly come to terms in a short time. During this time I saw Bauriesen, Goding, Frisby, Dumphy, & several others pass by on the opposite side of the street. We parted at 5.45 P.M. and I went to look for the men and found Frisby, Dumphy, and several others in Farrel's saloon, when I entered with Mr. Spellman and had some beer. Every body was talking about what a crowd they would have had in town and in the parade if it had not rained, which spoiled it all. Spellman and I left the saloon at 6.30 P.M. and went to our supper at #84 Fox St. There were a good many strangers in the place and I heard one of them remark, "I wonder how the strike stands?" and some one replied that it was just the same as when it was started except that both parties were getting sick of it, and if it was not for their pride they would give in, and out of the 400 men that were here he did not think was 100 left. We left there 7.15 P.M. and
Completed

went to the corner of Broadway and met Mortimer ands several other strong Democrats, I listened to them awhile and then left them and walked around the streets to see if I could learn any thing. I met Frisby & Dumphy at the corner of Main St. and I watched them for awhile and they went to #% River St. and I went into Schmidts cigar store, Dumphy came right out but Frisby remained there until 9.15 P.M. when he, Quinlain, and another man came out and started towards the Fox St. bridge, which they crossed and Frisby left them and went home.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton's Nat'l. Let. Agency
by W. A. Pinkerton
Genl. Supt. West. Div.
Completed

Chicago Sept. 22nd 1888.
H. B. Stone Esq
Genl. Mgr. C. B. & Q. R.R.
City.
Dear Sir:
Ofr. H.H.F. reports as follows.
Aurora, Thursday, Sept. 20th 88.
I left my room at 9 A.M. and went out to look for my men, I saw Westling and Mahoney standing at the Fox St. R.R. crossing talking to a brakeman of a passing train and when the caboose came along he jumped on and I heard him say, "I will do it." Westling and Mahoney then started down Fox St. and I kept out of their sight. At 10 A.M. I entered Hirsh's clothing store on Broadway and looked at the different club uniforms. He told me about the different parties and talked politics for awhile and finaly I spoke about the strike & he said the men had no cause whatever to strike, he said some of the men were making as high as $125.00 per month, but at the end of a year would not have as much money saved as the men who were only getting $1.00 to $1.50 per day. I asked him if the committee waited on him he said that it did not, but he expected it,
Completed

but he told Dumphy that he did not care a snap for the Brotherhood, and that if any man came in and wanted buy, he did not care if he was a "scab" or tramp so long as his money was good. He said he had lost the trade of the Brotherhood men, but the new men trade with him, and that he mostly traded with the farmers. I asked him if he had ever noticed any body try to persuade customers not to enter his store, and he said he never did, & said that they took good care that he should not see it as he would have them arrested at once. Just then two customers and a drummer entered and he went to wit up on them so I left. I saw Bauriesen in his buggy at 11.15 A.M. driving up Fox St. towards his home. At 2 P.M. I saw FRisby at the Corner of Fox St. and Broadway, I watched him from #113 and he was soon joined by Jacobs (bartender at Farrel's) and both went into Shorts saloon at 2.20 P.M. they came out and walked down Broadway and met Dumphy, Quinlain, Byron and White at the corner of Main St. where Jacobs and Frisby left and went into Farrel's saloon Shortly after I fell in with Hoyt Jr. and we went into Farrel's & had some beer. I found Frisby playing pool with Jacobs, we left at once and parted at the corner, I took a walk around town but heard
Completed

the people talk of nothing but politics. At 6 P.M. I met Mortimer on Fox St. bridge and we went into Farrel's and had some beer, from there we went to Fasmen's Cigar store #113 Fox St. and remained there until 7.15 P.M. talking. During our conversation I saw Bauriesen and shortly after Frisby pass by and when Mortimer and I started out we found them at the Car. of Main St. they entered the hall & I left Mortiner and went to the west side to Schmidts, while there I saw Frisby, Byron,& Quinlain enter the saloon #5 River St. I played three games of dominoes with Schmidt in the cigar store and also kept an eye on the saloon. At 9.15 they came out & I was just going to follow them when Westling & Mahoney came up and I could not get away from them, so I went down to the basement with them and had some beer and stood talking about different things. I asked Westling if he was not going to Chicago to look for work as he told me, he said he was going soon. I asked if any thing new had turned up in their favor, they said no that it stood just the same, except that the Company was getting poorer every day. We left at 10.30 P.M. & I went to look for Frisby but could not find him, and I went home at 11.45 P.M.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton's Nat'l. Let. Agcy
by W.A. Pinkerton
Gen'l. Supr. West. Div
R
Completed

Chicago Sept 24th 88
H.B. Stone Esq
Gen'l Mgr. C.B. & Q. R.R.
City
Dear Sir:
Ofsr. H.H. F reprots as follows, for Sept 21st & 22nd
Aurora, Friday, Sept 21st, 88,
At 9 A.M. I left my room to walk around town to see if I could meet any of my men, I saw Frisby at the Corner of Fox St. & Broadway, talking with Reed, I watched them from #113 Fox St. & at 10 A.M. they went to Young's cigar store, at 11 A.M. I saw Baureisen and Going on Broadway out side of Police Magistrate Murphy's office, during their stay at that place Frisby & Dumphy came up and all of them stood their until 11.45 A.M. I watched them from 27 Broadway. I again saw Frisby at 3 P.M. at the Imperial Hotel, from there he went to #5 River St. and I went to Schmidts cigar store, at 4 P.M. Frisby & Dumphy came out of the saloon, Frisby started towards the Fox St. bridge and went home. At 6.30 P.M. Mortimer met me at the corner of Fox St. and Broadway
Completed

and we went down to Farrel's and had some beer and I found Frisby there playing pool with Jacobs, (the bartender) Mortimer and I remained there until 7.15 P.M. when we left and took a walk up and down Broadway. At 8.15 P.M. I went to Reising's Hall to attend the dance and to get the opinion of the people there, who were scandinavians and strangers to me. Some of them were men who worked in the Q shops and some that worked in the watch factory. During the evening I had conversations with Hellgreen, Hakenson, Tivarson and three others whose names I do not know. They all said the men had no reason to strike as they were paid as much as the work was worth. These men took up a collection and brought two kegs of beer and some lemonade. We left the hall at 1 A.M.
Aurora, Sept. 22nd 1888
At 6.30 A.M. Frank Finch came to my room and asked me to go fishing with him to Montgomery. We started at 7 A.M. and went down to South Water St. to the ice cream factory and rented a boat and went down the river to Montgomery. I spoke about the strike & he said he had not spoken to the men since he came back from Omaha Neb. he said it was all most dangerous for the "scabs" to come
Completed

on the streets there, and if any of them got into trouble the police would arrest the "scabs" and let the others go whether they were guilty or not. He said most of the men had gone away and had jobs on other roads, but the few that were left seemed to stand firm, he said he thought the Company was getting ready to take the old men back again, as they would have to give in when winter comes as the new men were not used to it and will all leave. At 11 A.M. we left as the fish did not bite any more, and we arrived in town at 12 noon. We met Mortimer at the cor. of Fox St. & Broadway and we went to Farrel's and had beer. At 2 P.M. Mortimer came to my room and we remained there talking until 4 PM when we left and went to Short's saloon & had a glass of beer, and then walked down Broadway, I saw Frisby at the cor. of Main St. talking with Quintain & Byron, we walked to the Park and remained there until 5.30 P.M. when we went home. At 6 P.M. I went out to supper after which I walked around and met Frisby & Dumphy on York St. Bridge at 9.15 P.M. they went to #5 River St. and at 9.30 P.M. they left and Frisby went home.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton's Nat'l Det. Agcy
by W. A. Pinkerton
Gen'l. Supt. West. Div R
Completed

Chicago, Sept. 25th 1888
H.B. Stone Esq.
Gen'l. Mgr. C.B. and Q. R.R.
City
Dear Sir:
Following you will please find reports of Ofrs. F.W. and H.H.F.
Ofr. F.W. reports,
Aurora, Sunday, Sept 23rd,
To-day was a very quick one and there were very few strikes on the streets. One of the new men was leading a little girl down through Lincoln Park, and a daughter of Watkins, a striker, hallooed "scab" at him, I was with Jack O'Neil at the time and he said she ought to go home and hide her-self as she was too fast. I went to the Peoples Church where a great many of the striker's families go. In the afternoon I was around Young's cigar Store and also at Schiekler's, Mike Sently came to spend the day with the boys, he is working on the E.J.E. R.R. out of Elgin. S. Farnsworth is going out west. In the evening the strikers had a meeting after which I was
Completed

with Snovee?, who is now driving a coal wagon for Beilen, the livery man, and he said he was tired of attending those meetings where there was nothing done. During the evening I was around the corner of New York St. & Broadway for a long while, this being opposite the depot. I saw two tramps jump on the front end of the express car of the passenger that leaves here at 12.15 A.M. going west.
Ofr. H.H.F. reports:
Aurora, Sunday, Sept. 23rd, 88
At 9 A.M. I left my room and took a walk around town, I met Hoyd and Hakinson at 11 A.M. and we took a walk, and I spoke about the strike but they would say nothing except that the people on both sides were sick of it. Hold invited me to visit him in the evening. At 3 P.M. I met Mortimer on the street and we went to Tasmer's? Cigar store where we remained until 4.45 P.M. when I left and went out to see if I could find any of the men but did not see ay of them. At 6 P.M. I went to Hoyd's house #263 So. Water St. where I met Bordon, Hakinson, Olson, Rosetti, Anderson and Johnson all scandanavians.
Completed

we played dominoes & cards until 10 P.M. I could learn nothing about the strike as they would talk of nothing but politics. After I left there I took a walk around the streets and saw Frisby at the York St. Bridge talking to a couple of ladies but they parted and Frisby went home.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton's Nat'l Det. Agcy
by W.A. Pinkerton
Gen'l. Suppe. West. Div. 
R
Completed

Chicago, Sept 25th 88
H. B. Stone Esq
Gen'l. Mgr. C. B. & Q. R.R.
City
Dear Sir:
Ofr. F.W. reports as follows.
Aurora, Saturday, Sept 22nd 88
Today while in Young's I heard Pearson say that he was so tired of doing nothing, that he would work at whatever he could get to do. Charlie Dean a C.J. engineer is going away soon, to some place to run an engine but I do not know what road. A striking fireman by the name of Frank Keisev, went to work for Hick at the lunch counter. John Gretcout a striking engineer said to a stranger at the Depot to day that there was nothing in the Dynamite cases and they would soon be dropped. While at the Post Office I over heard a man talking about going to Geneva to Court, I again saw him in the hall way of the Brotherhood hall talking to a store keeper by the name of Riddle, and I thought this stranger might have something to do with
Completed

the cases there so I followed him until I found out that he was from Elgin and perhaps only stopped to talk with Mr. Riddle whose door is next to the Brother hood hallway. I was with Dumphy, Snover, Mears?, Farrell, Barry, Gretcout, Watkins, Byron, Raymond, McGraw, Dean, Pearson, Koegle and several others during the day. I saw Goding on the street. The strikers had quite a large meeting today. I heard from Joe Billings that the strikers had Alex Smith's father and mother fixed. In the evening I was around to Harris Hick's, Farrell's & Siebert's saloons with some of above named men, there was a fight at Farrell's but not between R.R. men. I was around the Depot until after 3 A.M. Vic. Raymond & Tom Barry remained there until about 3 A.M. when they went home. Every thing was quiet.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton's Nat'l Det. Agcy
by W.A. Pinkerton
Gen'l. Supt. West. Div. 
R
Completed

Chicago, Sept. 26th 88
H.B. Stone Esq
Gen'l. Mgr. C.B. & Q. R.R.
City
Dear Sir:
Ofr. H.H.F. reports as follows:
Aurora, Ill. Sept 24th 88
I started out at the usual time this morning and took a walk around town. I met Frisby on Broadway at 10 A.M. he went to the Post office and remained in that vicinity as there was an election going on during the day. I stood on the Fox St. bridge for awhile and Barlow came along and asked me to go with him, we went to #19 Broadway, a saloon, where we met Olson, Rosetti, Hoyd, Anderson, and Dalin, we had some beer and I spoke about the strike but it was impossible to get any thing from them as they were so interested in the election. I left there at 11.45 A.M. and walked around the city. Frisby was still around the city hall in the afternoon. At 6.20 P.M. as I was in the back
Completed

yard a freight train passed and I heard another train coming in behind it, and at the same time heard the signal for brakes, and jumping to the fence which is next to the track I saw the engine of the last train smash into the waycar of the first train pushing in half way into the freight car a head. The escaping steam drove me from the fence but as soon as it had gone I jumped into the freight car, and there found two horses and as far as I could see both were unhurt. The brakeman and a man that had care of the horses came in at the same time and I heard them say that the trains had been following each other for some time and that the engine in the rear had come in at full speed and when there was going to be a collision they jumped. From people that came to the wreck I heard the same story, I heard the following remarks passed, "any scabs killed" "it is so foggy that they could not see." "pity it did not kill any of the scabs." &c. I remained in the vicinity until 7.15 P.M. but nothing more was said, the people seemed to be more interested in the horses, which were race horses, the than they did of the men. I met Dumphy at the
Completed

Cor. of Main St. & Broadway, and I told him there was quite a wreck in town and he replied, "Yes, I heard about it,  but d--- the road, we are too busy with politics, come and vote," and then hurried away. I heard but little about the wreck in one place on Broadway. I overheard a conversation and heard it was pure carelessness and nothing else that caused the wreck. I met Hoyd Hokinson & Barlow and we went to #19 Broadway and we had some beer, I left there at 9 P.M. and saw Mr. Rhodes and made a verbal report of the wreck. I left Mr. Rhodes at 10.10 P.M. and went down Broadway to locate Frisby, I saw him go into Farrell's with Quinlain, and they came out at 10.30 P.M. and Frisby went home.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton's Nat'l Det. Agcy
by W.A. Pinkerton
Gen'l. Supt. West. Div.
R.
Completed

Chicago September 26. 1888.
H.B. Stone Esq.
Dear Sir:
Following find report of Ofr. F.W. dated at Aurora Ills. Sept. 24th (Monday) 1888.
Ofr. reports: that today the Democrats had a primary meeting for the nomination of Representation from the 14th Senatorial District! There were two men put up: one Geo Heartz (the man who sold Bowles the blue Vitriol.) but he is not supported by the strikers- Luther M. Dearborn being the man the strikers are supporting and Daniel Alschuler seems to be the Leader among the strikers: Ofr. encloses a copy of the Ticket. Ofr was around the Voting place and says a great many of the strikers are republicans everything is politics there at present. that a daily paper (Rep) came out and denied that the strikers were going to vote the Democrat Ticket on acct of the C.B. & Q. men being republicans: - Tom Barry who is working hard for the success of the republican Ticket says that the strikers will all vote for Palmer on acct of his Hatred of the Pinkerton's but that it was nonsense for anyone to belive anything like that: That any individual could persecute and have punished, any person for arming a private body of men.
Ofr. says that in the Evening about 630 p.m. a Freight Train which was standing on the Track between
Completed

Fox and Benton Sts was run into by an Engine of the Gravel Train: Breaking the front of their Engine and pushing a freight car through a Caboose There happened to be two race horses in the freight car one the (Plano? Boy) and the other a horse belonging 
fold in original report prevents the following line from being transcribed
Ofr says he thinks neither Horse was hurt. This accident caused lots of talk among the strikers and at Youngs Cigar Store: Hank Young said he wished both Horses had been killed and then the Company would have to pay for them: and Young also said that the Engineer and Fireman of the Engine that ran into the Caboose had left their post of duty: and Could not be found also that the Engine of the Gravel Train had been following the Freight a long time and knew there was a Freight right ahead of them.
In the Evening Opt was at Youngs with Gretcourt Pearson, Miller, Mears and DeGerald and Leo Young talking on different subjects: was also at Farrells with Tom Kyle Westling McGinn, Raymond and others playing pool and later Opt was at Heirls? saloon with Snover, Bary, Santley Weldon and others and also at the lunch counter of Harris saloon, talking until a late hour but learned nothing other than above reported:
Yours Respectfully
Pinkertons National Detective Agency
per Wm A. Pinkerton Genl. Supt.

Chicago Illinois
Sept 27. 1888.
H.B. Stone Esq.
Genl. Manager. C.B. & Q. R.R.
City
Dear Sir:
Following find report of Opt. F.W. dated at Aurora. Tuesday Sept. 25th 1888. Operative reports as follows:
That Today in Aurora He was with Snover Sently and Koegel in Hecks Rsstaurant, and Koegel was trying to get Opt to vote the Democratic Ticket or to vote for Palmer. Koegel said that Opt had seen enough of the Pinkerton Son of B-----s while Opt had been in town, so that Opt. ought to help get rid of them And Santly said: Yes, and to wait till after November, Opt asked him if he meant the November Election: Santly said no, the November term of Court Next weeks the grand Jury sits at Geneva and then it would be found out what was to be done- Opt says but few of the strikers go to Youngs Cigar Store any more: Opt met Joe Hoppy Tom. Weldon and a few others: (strikers) Opt played dominoes with DeGerald, Leo Young, Pearson and
Completed

McGraw. all the conversation was about the accident last night and about politics, At Farrells Saloon. Opt met Mears, Fairchild Frisbee and others: Opt played pool with these men. Opt saw Bauereisen and John Greburt. talking together. Opt was also over at the Democrat Office and had a talk with Dumphy
Opt was also in Gramps and Seiberts saloon. Opt saw a letter that Bauereisen put in the box it had Mendota on it but Opt could not see the name on it:
There was a Parade in the evening by the Republicans: Opt was standing in front of the Brotherhood Hall and the Streets were crowded. Opt saw a Stranger come out of there: he answers Smokey Deweys discription to a T. Opt says he looks like and answers Bowles discription only is strieghter than Bowles and not quite as tall, as Bowles Opt shadowed this man, after the Parade. he walked around Town went in the Martin Saloon, he met a Freight Brakesman on the Q. home he shook hands with: they walked to the Depot. and the Brakesman jumped a Caboose and rode up into the Yards but the Straner remained at the Depot and took the 12.05 A.M. train West without buying a Ticket, Opt at first thought the man was Bowles, he is not the man
Completed

Bowles said was his brother, who took him off the road, as Opt knows him and has watched for him there:
Opt remained about the Depot and Tracks until after 2 A.M. and then discontinued.
Yours Truly.
Pinkerton National Detective Agcy
per Wm A Pinkerton Genl. Supt.
Western Division
Completed

Chicago, Sept 3rd 88
H.B. Stone Esq
Gen'l. Mgr. C.B. & Q. R.R.
City
Dear Sir:
Following you will please find reports of Ofr. H.H.F. for Aug 31st and Sept. 1st
Friday, Aug 31st 1888
Today in Aurora Ofr. met Ofr. F.W.at the Post office at 8 A.M. and received instructions from Asst. Supt. J.C.McG. through Ofr F.W. to pay more attention to the general opinion of the citizens and less to Westling & Maloney. At 9.15 A.M. he saw Goding & Frisby at the corner of LaSalle and Fox Sts. where they stood talking until 10.30 A.M. where they left and Ofr. took a walk around the streets to see if he could find Baureisen but did not see him, Ofr. entered the Drug store at 27 Broadway and got a cigar and had a talk with the clerk about different things, and soon about the strike, he told Ofr. that the strikers were fools, who thought they could run the world as they pleased, during the conversation Mr. C.L. Hoyt of the firm Hoyt & Bros.
Completed

& Co. entered and he denounced the strikers and said they were fools and that he always thought so and that he always would. that he was not like some who were with the Company at first, but as soon as the Committee waited up on them, what did they do but take their freight on the North Western and denounce the Company, but that it was all for money and he thought that there were a good many of them who in their hearts thought the Company was right. Ofr. left the Drug store in company with Mr. Hoyt and went to see his (Hoyt's) shops where Ofr. met Mr. Morthimer and a machinist named Olson and as soon as Mr. Hoyt left for his office got into a conversation and found that about two thirds of the 150 men there were with the strikers the others being on the Company's side. Morthimer asked Ofr. to go to the theater with him in the evening and for him to go and buy the tickets at once, so Ofr. went to Biddle's & Shickler's store on Broadway to buy them at 2 P.M. and got to talking to the clerk there and they were just on the point of the strike when some customers came in and stopped the conversation, & Ofr. left and went to the corner of Fox St. where he met Mr Finch and one of his men and they ask
Completed

ed him down to Farrel's saloon, he went with them and they had some beer and had a little talk about the strike but they were both on the striker's side. Mr. Finch said it was best to keep quiet as the Company would get the best of the boys. When Ofr. came out of the saloon he saw Frisby at the corner so he watched him until 4 P.M. when he went to Young's Cigar store and Ofr. walked around but did not hear any thing about the strike. He saw Frisby again at 7 P.M. going to the hall. At 8 P.M. Ofr. went to the theater with Mortimer and tried to rope him but he would not talk. Ofr. learned that the committee of strikers had gone around to all business men in the town and said they would boycotte them if they had any dealings with the "Q."
Saturday, Sept 1st 1888
Today in Aurora Ofr. started out at 8 A.M. and found Frisby at Young's cigar store, he left him there and took a walk around to see if he could hear any thing about the strike, but the people are all interested in Politics and in preparing for the Labor picnic to be held Monday. At 10 A.M. Ofr. saw a crowd at Fasmers Cigar store so he entered and
Completed

got a cigar and sat down and listened to the conversation but as it was all about politics, he left and found Frisby at the Corner of Fox St. & Broadway, he watched him from #27 Broadway until 11.45 A.M. when he (Frisby) went home. In the afternoon Ofr. met Mortimer, Mr. Spellman, & C. Hoyt Jr. at the Corner of Downer Place & River St, and they asked him to go to the ball game, so he went with them and on the way he had a talk with Mr. Spellman about the strike and he said the men did wrong in striking and did still worse in using force and trying to molest the Company's property as they lost all the sympathy of all the right thinking citizens , still the working men keep their side as a matter of fact between capital and labor & don't give themselves time to think or rather don't take the trouble to look into the matter properly. When they were returning from the ball game Ofr. saw Westling and two policeman going down River St. in a hurry, it was impossible for Ofr. to leave the party, but he got them to walk a little faster, when they came to the City Hall Ofr. saw the patrol wagon in which there were two men whom the officers had arrested, there was such a large crowd that Ofr. could not learn
Completed

all, but he spoke a few words to Westling who said that he was going under some bridge in a boat and two :scabs" drove over the bridge in a buggy and shot at him and the bullet came close to him. There was a large crowd around Westling and Ofr's party was calling him (Ofr.) so he left, but soon got separated from them and went to #8 River St. to see if Westling was there but he was not and Ofr. went to his house and did not find him there. He looked for him all evening but failed to see him. At 8.30 P.M. Ofr. again saw Mortimer & Spellman and Ofr. went with them to Farrelis saloon, and while there, Frisby, Reed, Hewitt, Dumphy, Quinlain and a few more rail-road men and outsiders entered The men were very excited and denounced the "scabs" by all the hard words they could use and said if they only had those two men in their hands they would lynch them to the first lamp post. Opr. and his friends listened to the talk and were joined by C. Hoyt Jr. & E. Hoyt. Mortimer wanted Opr. to go home with him and at 10.15 P.M. they both left the place and went home and as soon as Mortimer went to his room and went to bed Opr. went out again and found a crowd at the
Completed

corner of Fox St. & Broadway talking about the shooting affair, Opr. passed them and heard one of them say, "Boys, let us all go home and do nothing that we will be sorry for." at 11.30 P.M. they began to leave for home and Frisby started for his home at 12 midnight and every thing was quiet. Opr. walked around until 2 A.M. to see if the men would gather at any place with the intentions of doing harm but there was no such gathering at anyplace. A 2 A.M. Opr. went to his room and was about to go to bed when he heard a lot of men coming from the south on LaSalle. he put his clothes on at once and started after them, he followed them east on Fox St. and caught up to them at the bridge and saw that they were young clerks from the different stores in the city coming from some party so he left them and returned home.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton's Nat'l. Det. Agcy
by Q.A. Pinkerton
Gen'l. Supt. West. Div.
A.R.
Completed

Chicago, Sept 6th, 1888,
H.B. Stone Esq.
Genl. Mangr. C.B. & Q. R.R.
Chicago
Dear Sir.
Following find report of Opt. H.H.F. dated at Aurora Sept 4th 1888:
Operative reports that at 7.30 this am. Sept 4th Mortimer told Opt he was not going to work and asked if they could not spend the day together. and take a ride together to the Country in and during the forenoon: Opt. expected to find out from Mortimer about the committee so said he would go with him. They started at 8 o'clock a.m. and got a rig at the Broadway Surry Stable and started for Bataria taking a case of beer with them. also cigars: When they arrived at Bataria they drove around the town. they went to Geneva. Opt. could not get Mortimer to talk of anything other than politics most of the time. but finally succeeded in turning the talk to the Labor question and then to the strike Opt says he learned from Mortimer that a Committee of 2 Strikers had waited upon every business man along the line of the CB&Q. system from Chicago to Denver: Col. and with threats of Boycotte wanted them to deal with any other Road other than the "Q"- and that just before the
Completed

Chicago convention. they waited upon every delegation and tried to have them take some other route: if possible. Opt was unable to get the full list of the Committee but learned that Dumphy and Henley were two of the: they got back to Aurora at 2 p.m. - and at 3 p.m. Opt found Frisby at cor of Fox & B. way and Goding and Baueriesen at no. 8 B. Way Opt watched them from Drug Store no 27. Way until 3.45 when Frisby went to Youngs - the others stayed where Opt 1st saw them until 4.30 pm. Opt was at the Cor of Fox St when Westling came and asked Opt to go to no 19 B.Way a saloon. Opt went had some beer there: during this time Goding and Bauereisen: left at 6 p.m. Opt saw Frisby go home at 6.30 Mortimer and Opt started out and went to the Corner of York St. he wanted Opt to go to the Park. but Opt. having an appointment to meet Opt Wind at 4 p.m. he excused himself by telling him he had to meet his girl but would see him at 8 o'clock After Opt left Mortimer. he saw Mr Rhodes crossing York St. Opt then went to meet Opt W. at 7.15 Opt W. came and told OptH.H.F. there was a letter for him at the post Office. - Opt got his letter and then went to join Mortimer - Opt thinks he can best get acquainted with the business men and get their opinions on the strike and Boycotte question
Opt found Mortimer at 113 Fox St. - they then talked but could get nothing of importance. All the talk now is politics and Opt thinks it will be so for the remainder of the week. - they will have the 6th democratic meeting - the whole atmosphere so.
Completed

Opt says is politics! Opt. Mortimer and Tasmer went to Shorts saloon. had several drinks there were a number of the strikers there all discussing political questions - at 10.15 Frisby went home. and Opt then too Mortimer Home:
Yours Truly
W.A. Pinkerton
pwH.?
Completed

Chicago, Sept 11th. 1888
H.B. Stone Esq
Gen'l. Mgr. C.B. & Q. R.R.
City
Dear Sir:
Following you will please find report of Opr. H.H.F.
Sunday, Sept 9th 88
Today in Aurora Opr. left his room at 9 A.M. and walked around town and met Frisby at 11 A.M. on Fox St. and Opr. went into #113 Fox St. and bought a cigar and then sat down on the side walk and at the same time Mortimer came up and talked with Opr. until 12 noon when Opr. saw Frisby walk towards Broadway so he asked Mortimer to take a walk. Frisby went to the Imperial Hotel, and Opr. & Mortimer walked over the York St. bridge and went to Schmidts cigar Store no. 8 River St. He (Opr.) had promised Schmidt to let him know whether he was going to join the club, they went in and had some cigars and talked politics. Opr. left there at 1 P.M. and went home. At 2.30 P.M. he met Mr. Barlow a tailor at 17 Broadway and
Completed

Mr. Burns, they asked him to go to the camp meeting in Even's Park. Opr. went with them and he saw a good many of the strikers there, Opr. got talking to Mr. Barlow about the strike and he said the men did a foolish thing and as they were talking Mr. Barlow's brother came up and said that he always said that the men should think twice before striking & said he never saw a strike than did any good. They left there at 4.30 P.M. and made up a party to go to north Aurora in the afternoon & Burns promised to get them a small keg of beer. They started at 6.15 P.M. & went to the house of Swedish family by the name of Olson, the man works in the N. Aurora Mill. There was quite a number of men and girls at the house and they danced and playd games. Opr. got into a conversation with Olson & two other men about the strike. They said that the boys had made a foolish move, but it could not be helped, as they heard the Company would not take any of the old men back, but the old men still think the company cannot do without them. Opr. left Mr. Barlow's buggy at Fox St bridge and walked around to see if any of the men were around but up to 12 p.m. he did not see any of them so he discontinued.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton's Nat'l. Det. Agcy
by W.A. Pinkerton
Genl. Supt. West Div
